story:
HISTORY

The East Coast - based Cassera family art business was founded by the late George D. Cassera in 1960. Over the past 50 years, the gallery has maintained a strong emphasis on fine art and design. In 2011, David A. Cassera opened two Pacific Northwest gallery locations (Vancouver B.C. and LaConner, WA) while maintaining a seasonal New York City presence. David, the youngest son of four boys, is an international specialist in the traditional arts of Africa, Oceania and the Americas. David has continued with his father’s fine art and design legacy with an additional focus on ‘Primitivism’. ‘Primitivism’ is a Western art movement that borrows visual forms from non-Western or indigenous peoples, such as Picasso’s embrace of African and Oceanic sculpture during the dawn of Cubism. Cassera utilizes his inherent design talent in juxtaposition with his vast knowledge of ancient cultures to emphasize how borrowings from ‘Primitive Art’ has been important to the development of modern and contemporary art. David provides sales, expertise and professional fine art appraisals for single items or entire collections.

AGENDA

David Cassera has an extensive history in fine art and marketing. His gallery business model consists of Fine Art, Music and Wine. David would like to bring this experience to Camano Island in the Spring of 2017. Utilizing the space discussed David plans to build display walls, build a wine bar, install lighting, etc. The space would be multi-use for wine tasting, art receptions and live musical performances, something Camano Island is currently missing.

THE ART

Utilizing the vast network of artists David knows personally on Camano Island, Seattle, and the Skagit Valley he plans to create a rotating schedule of events known simply as ‘art receptions’. This would include between 3-5 themed ‘Group Shows’ a year, ie; Bird Show, Landscape Show, Figural Show, etc. In addition there would be 4-6 artist ‘one man’ shows determined by quality and artistic merit. The works would be for sale based on the demographic of consumers on the island. Openings would be scheduled and marketed based on the best days, times and seasons to encourage local Camano Islanders to stay involved in the Camano ‘Art Scene’ that we will revive once again.

I NEED

  • $3,000 to put towards construction and marketing.
  • Community support for the arts.
  • Help getting the word out, please tell your neighbors and friends.

CONTRIBUTORS OF $250 or MORE WILL RECEIVE

  • VIP status
  • 10% off wine purchases.
  • 10% discount on art purchases
  • A space you will enjoy in all seasons.
  • Satisfaction knowing you are helping support the arts in our community.

CONTRIBUTORS OF $100 or MORE WILL RECEIVE

  • VIP status
  • 10% off wine purchases.
  • A space you will enjoy in all seasons.
  • Satisfaction knowing you are helping support the arts.

If you just can't contribute money right now, that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • You can get the word out and make some noise about my campaign.
  • Share on social media!

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

story:
My name is William Franken (www.willfranken.com), an award-winning, critically-acclaimed comedian and satirist whose work has been praised on both sides of the Atlantic, from the Guardian to the late Robin Williams. Twenty years ago, before embarking on a performing career, I was a university level literature instructor with an obsession for the pre-Romantic movement, of which William Blake is arguably the central artistic and literary figure. This project, for me, is a whirlwind return to a lifelong passion. 

Please help support the creation of the William Blake documentary, Red, White, and Blake. Unlike other films on Blake, this work will largely eschew the well-known biographical details of the poet’s life, instead drilling down on a four-fold exploration of his visionary works. Using his poetry and art themselves as guiding spirits, we will highlight Blake's radical theological vision, contempt for all forms of physical and mental slavery, support for the political revolutions of his day, and, most importantly, his contrarian vision of authentic artistic progress. 

Structurally, the work will be an homage to Blake’s unique mythology of the Four Zoas, with each fifteen-minute section in the hour-long programme focusing on one aspect of Blake’s own four-fold vision.

The intent is to present this documentary as a pilot to BBC Four as part one in a series tentatively entitled Rebels in the Arts, (with prospectuses on Jonathan Swift, James Joyce, and others to follow).

If you're unfamiliar with the works of William Blake, this documentary will serve as an excellent starting point from which to understand this singular visionary genius. On the other hand, if, like me, you are a fellow Blake enthusiast, this film will add unique and compelling layers of historical and philosophical context to your appreciation of his works. 

The budget of £2,500 is to support the production as we work towards the goal of an August 2017 release.  We will focus our energies on ensuring we produce an accurately-researched, informative, and thought-provoking documentary, whilst continuing to scout locations, rifle through the Blake archives at the Tate Museum and British Library, procure interviews with Blake scholars and theological experts, and secure music copyrights where need be. 

For those already familiar with Blake's Four Zoas -- or for those keen to learn -- below is a chapter-by-chapter structural breakdown of the project. (And thank you in advance for your support!)

ZOA I: THARMAS [THEOLOGY] will cover Blake’s unique understanding of the Divine Duality of Man. It begins with an historical contextualisation of Blake’s early radical background as the son of English Dissenters. From his rebellion against the established Anglican Church of his day, the historical lens is widened to accommodate the shifts in ethical understanding brought about earlier by the Enlightenment, particularly in the works of Immanuel Kant, and from there to the radical cosmology of the Swedish mystic Emanuel Swedenborg, an early theological influence on the young William Blake. The section will conclude with Blake’s ultimate rejection of Swedenborgian cosmology in favour of his own unique system of a necessary duality, evident in such rebellious works as The Marriage of Heaven and Hell.  

ZOA II: URIZEN [SLAVERY] will deal with Blake’s broad contempt for slavery. Using as a departure point his revolutionary credo “I must create a system or be enslaved by another man’s”, this Zoa will begin with Blake’s rejection of the fashionable 18th Century schools of art, highlighting in particular Blake’s venom for the portrait painter Sir Joshua Reynolds. Blake’s own unique hybrid of visual art intertwined with the written word, as well as his elaborate mythology concerning the fall and division of the God-Man Albion into Four Zoas, will set the thematic stage for Blake’s rejection of any and all enslaving systems. From his engravings for John Stedman’s book on the slave plantations of Surinam to poems like “Little Black Boy”, his repulsion against physical slavery will come into focus. From there, the too-often overlooked negative consequences of the Industrial Revolution are explored in, among many other works, both versions of “The Chimney Sweeper”. Finally, Blake’s broader disgust at mental, spiritual, and creative slavery are realised in the “mind-forg’d manacles” of “London” in addition to his starkly critical portrait of Isaac Newton, from which parallels will be drawn to the technological, ideological, and economical enslavements of our own postmodern times. 

ZOA III: LUVAH [LIBERTY] will draw attention to Blake’s unique historical position as a pre-Romantic political visionary, heralding the dawn of a new era wherein the rights of individual man are championed in the American and French Revolutions. As the 18th Century comes to a close, Blake’s optimism for the anti-monarchical movements sweeping both the continent and the colonies is seen through his literary prism as Man’s spiritual trudge towards Divine destiny. Drawing heavily upon Blake’s larger prophetic works, notably America and Europe, we see how the dispassionate emphasis on reason which characterised the early 18th Century failed to anticipate, in its heavily-ordered view of the universe, the demands for liberty and justice that would emerge at the century’s close.

ZOA IV: URTHONA [CONTRARY] will be an extensive recapitulation of the first three Zoas, drawing upon Blake’s later works, namely Milton and Jerusalem, en route to a critical modern-day application of his profound axiom: “Without Contraries is No Progression”. This Zoa begins with William Blake’s sedition trial in Sussex at the start of 1804, an historical springboard by which to analyse his belief in the necessity of division for arriving at artistic, cultural, and political truths. Aside from Blake’s own understanding of Biblical scripture, parallels to the work of the German contemporary Friedrich Hegel as well as various schools of Eastern thought, specifically Taoism, will serve as philosophical underpinnings to justify, in all fields of human endeavour, the rejection of a monolithic status quo. The impassioned cries from more obscure uprisings like the Luddite Rebellion of 1811 to the larger Romantic movement as a whole, will echo down to our present age by means of Blake's far-seeing prophetic artistic filter.

story:
Guppy: Feed and Be Fed.

Unlike existing social networking platforms, Guppy will let you lock your content and share them exclusively with those followers who pay a donation to support you. The collected donation will then be split between you and a charity of your choice. This exchange results in building a deeper connection with your avid supporters who truly value you. It will also allow you to monetize for yourself as well as for a cause you care deeply about.

This self-sustaining ecosystem of "give and receive" is what I call "Feed and Be Fed" and I am finally working to make this vision a reality. Check out our instagram page to find out the details of how the app will look and function→ https://www.instagram.com/weareguppy/

What We Need & What You Get

About four months ago, I decided to invest my time and money into actually developing this platform and so far the design and screens for the app have been completed and we have just started coding. As you may know, an app start-up is not cheap and my limited financing has held me back from moving the project forward.

With your monetary support, I will be able to pay the developers as well as an attorney to draft an operating agreement, privacy policy, terms and condition for the company, and also incorporate the company.

I'm truly grateful for all your support and I'd like to give back by offering some perks to those who decide to financially support my project. You can check out the details on the right side of this page!

If you don't feel comfortable making a monetary contribution, you can still support by spreading the word and sharing this page!


I know this journey is all about trial and error and there will be many bumps along the way, but I will do my best to finalize the app as soon as possible so that we can all benefit from it!


Thank you so much for taking the time to read this. Your generosity means so much to me and I promise it will not be wasted.


Please feel free to reach out to me if you have any questions or feedback on the project! weareguppyusa@gmail.com

Check out our Instagram and/or Facebook page  https://www.instagram.com/weareguppy/, https://www.facebook.com/Guppy-Feed-and-Be-Fed-...

story:
Dearest friends and family, familiar and far..

WE NEED YOUR HELP!

The challenge? €3000 in 2 weeks?!

With your help we can do it!

Emerging artists, industry professionals and inquisitive minds collide in a smorgous board of creativity and madness, transforming a 700 year old palace into an immersive arts experience.

♕

'Edinburgh Fringe meets Burning Man with the unique backdrop of a Polish Palace - this will take off, mark my words' - Robert Goodale, Olivier Award Winner

♕

The Concept?

100 artists take over a 700 year old palace for 2 weeks

Everyone contributes, whether by giving a talk, a workshop, a skill or simply as an active audience member.

The aim is to collaborate, network and create; support, learn and inspire

The result? - A totally unique and inspired showcase in the from of an immersive arts festival

♕

We aim to help early career creatives transform skill into professional opportunity by providing a platform to showcase and develop work, that spring boards creative, social and environmental projects on a local and international level. 

With our second year on the horizon, The Palace is now an ever growing international hub for artists and a testing ground for innovative ideas. 

As an independent, non profit company, we need your support to help provide the standard and quality required to really make a difference to our artists and their work. 

OUR ARTISTS:

http://www.thepalacearts.org/contributor-index

 

Who's involved? Whats going down?

Artists 2017: www.thepalacearts.org/contributor-index

Projects 2017: www.thepalacearts.org/projects

Press: www.thepalacearts.org/reading-1

Galleries 2016: www.thepalacearts.org/photos

Footage 2016: www.thepalacearts.org/footage

New to The Palace 2017:

The Palace International Film Festival 

The new branch of The Palace is an underground film festival set in a barn loft in The Palace. The Blue Flamingo Cinema is an immersive exhibition space decorated with up-cycled CD sculpture and a blue neon tacky aesthetic. The program will screen topics from sex positivity to the refugee crisis, and American Black Lives Matter to Icelandic queer experimental. http://www.palacefilmfest.org

Sustainable Fashion and Festival Design 

With the advent of Donald trump we’ve decided to save the world. This year sees a plethora of fashion designers descending on The Palace to transform rags to riches with collection centres for disregarded clothes set up across London, Berlin and Barcelona. The Sunday closing carnival will see drag queens and acrobats strut the dungeon catwalk creations incorporating natural dying and festival waste. The Palace courtyard will also be home to the up-cycle and recycle centre, where local polish antiquities meet Berlin brutalist art, concrete and rubbish collide to form sculptures that will embellish the site, and sold on after the event.

The Artists Residency 

This year the residency has been extended to 7 days with a fully formed program of workshops, talks, classes and events.The work developed will be featured with in a daily 'progress exhibition' in the main hall and then at opening Festival Friday Gala as an immersive tour through the site of performance and art. Saturday will host the Market Bazaar, where work and art will be sold and traded. Our vision is to become a creative retreat that is recognised for its learning opportunities and collaborative works.

Wellbeing at The Bell Tent 

With its own series of workshops, treatments and talks focused on art as therapy, The Bell Tent will be a place of solitude and creative reflection. Set in and around the lake island in the Palace gardens.

 

Artist Diversity Figures 2017:

 

With your help, our friends, family and creative communities we can keep this incredible project going!

For more detail download our INFO PACK HERE

Be a benefactor of an emerging world of art and enable young creators to test, challenge, innovate and inspire.

♕♕♕

www.thepalacearts.org

story:
Bring to life an Eiffel Tower in Burning Man

Dusty Frogz is a BM French theme camp. As an official camp, we need a landmark. What's the most obvious defining French community, if not the Eiffel Tower? 
Burners would never get lost, like if they were enjoying a ballade in Paris. Our Eiffel Tower would be a basic place to find one's way, day and night, with its 7m high enlightened structure.

Like the original monument gathering people around the world, join the experiment to share how you feel rooted to this spirit of freedom. Burners can also join and play Petanque under the Eiffel Tower!

The Eiffel Tower story is one the most amazing of existing monuments. Like all BM installations the original Eiffel Tower was supposed to be short lived and destroyed at the end of the 1889 Universal Exposure in Paris. Fortunately people got amazed by its architecture, and Paris would not let it go. 

We wont burn it though and if you really enjoy it, we'll try and bring it back next year, but even better. The Iron lady won't disappoint!

 

What We Need

Our Eiffel Tower will be made of wood and covered in 10 000 LEDs to lit it up at night. Your contribution will entirely go to the construction and all extra will be dedicated to a higher structure and extra gifts to you ;)

Equipment

Jig saw and blades, hammers, etc - EUR 300

Materials

Lumbers / Nails - EUR 500

10 000 LEDs - EUR 1000

Batteries to power lights - EUR 600

Truck - EUR 600

What You Get

From your name on our Eiffel Tower + a picture posted on your Instagram to Eiffel Tower miniatures shipped to your home with a bit of Playa dust!

Risks & Challenges

We've been preparing this project from around the world (team members are based in Paris, Montpellier, New Caledonia...), gathering artists, engineers, sculptors and more inspired people. Reuniting ideas, drafting, preparing the building is not easy when apart! And contrary to most of teams bringing art to Burning Man, we are not based in the US, and being away is one of our biggest challenges.

Once we set foot in California, we will have to buy all materials, bring them to the Playa and THEN finally, raise the Eiffel Tower in the dust from scratch! 

For that, all the peeps in our camp will get their hands dirty and build up our very own monument!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you adhere to this project but unfortunately can't participate, please share our link we will be forever grateful!

Other way is if you have useful tools you want to get rid off, and that you live in San Francisco or Reno, please contact us, we might need all we can get ;)

Dusty Frogz is a BM French theme camp. As an official camp, we need a landmark. What's the most obvious defining French community, if not the Eiffel Tower? Burners would never get lost, like if they were enjoying a ballade in Paris. Our Eiffel Tower would be a basic place to find one's way, day and night, with its 7m high enlightened structure.
Like the original monument gathering people around the world, join the experiment to share how you feel rooted to this spirit of freedom. Burners can also join and play Petanque under the Eiffel Tower!
The Eiffel Tower story is one the most amazing of existing monuments. Like all BM installations the original Eiffel Tower was supposed to be short lived and destroyed at the end of the 1889 Universal Exposure in Paris. Fortunately people got amazed by its architecture, and Paris would not let it go. 
We wont burn it though and if you really enjoy it, we'll try and bring it back next year, but even better. The Iron lady won't disappoint!
 

What We Need
Our Eiffel Tower will be made of wood and covered in 10 000 LEDs to lit it up at night. Your contribution will entirely go to the construction and all extra will be dedicated to a higher structure and extra gifts to you ;)

Equipment
Jig saw and blades, hammers, etc - EUR 300
Materials
Lumbers / Nails - EUR 500
10 000 LEDs - EUR 1000
Batteries to power lights - EUR 600
Truck - EUR 600
What You Get
From your name on our Eiffel Tower + a picture posted on your Instagram to Eiffel Tower miniatures shipped to your home with a bit of Playa dust!
Risks & Challenges

We've been preparing this project from around the world (team members are based in Paris, Montpellier, New Caledonia...), gathering artists, engineers, sculptors and more inspired people. Reuniting ideas, drafting, preparing the building is not easy when apart! And contrary to most of teams bringing art to Burning Man, we are not based in the US, and being away is one of our biggest challenges.
Once we set foot in California, we will have to buy all materials, bring them to the Playa and THEN finally, raise the Eiffel Tower in the dust from scratch! 
For that, all the peeps in our camp will get their hands dirty and build up our very own monument!

Other Ways You Can Help
If you adhere to this project but unfortunately can't participate, please share our link we will be forever grateful!
Other way is if you have useful tools you want to get rid off, and that you live in San Francisco or Reno, please contact us, we might need all we can get ;)

story:
Art & inspiration 

I've been a full time artist since 2010. Dedicating myself to using art and technology to tell stories. My dream is to use this series of books and art to eventually create a documentary called "What Will Tomorrow Bring"

In Africa, the voice was the first human instrument. Used around sacred fires to tell stories. "WWTB" is a documentary of humanities return back to the sacred fire. To remind ourself that we all began as a family. Now, as a family, we must unite in our efforts to build a better tomorrow.

This campaign will help begin a incremental growth of relationship between supporters and create a community to make this dream a reality. One book at a time!

Creating volume: 1

This campaign will use the $800 to create the first 25 books.

Binding Method: Hardcover
Cover Option: Printed
End Leaf: White
Orientation: Portrait
Dust Cover: yes
Cover Finish: Gloss Film Lamination
Page Size: 9.0 x 12.0 in
Print Option: Two Sided
Paper Stock: #80 Glossy or Matte 
Black/White Pages: 13
Color Pages: 12
Total Pages: 25
Book Quantity: 25

Perks range from prints to first edition signed books!

Purpose

A global family reunion:

 

"WWTB" is an opportunity to reflect on human kinds birth from Africa. Huddled together in our infancy. Unsure of what laid beyond the darkness of the fire. Now, we use those same flames to create divisions out of fear.

 

"WWTB" is a moment to remind us all the great journey we have survived as a species. To remind ourselves that we all began as one family. Now, as a family, we must unite in our efforts to build a better tomorrow. 

- International collaboration: 

We want to work closely with "Rwanda Development Board" Which is set up to bring all government agencies responsible for investment promotion, environmental clearance and business registration. 

Helping bring people like Es Devlin, stage designer. "Known for the London closing ceremony, and the Rio opening ceremony" together with MDH. World leader in 3D hologramic technology. Rendering prolific musicians such as Bob Marley and gifted speakers such as Martin Luther King.

 

Creating something the world has never seen. A global collaboration of musicians, performers and speakers. Dead and living.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share, share, share!

story:
Who We Are

With Food in Mind develops art-based approaches to food education and food injustice. Our projects collectively explore the potential of visual art and artists to impart nutritional knowledge and to affect change in childhood obesity in low-income neighborhoods and communities of color. 

What We're Doing

On July 11, With Food in Mind's running team will take part in the LoziLu Women’s 5K Mud Run at the Aviator Sports and Event Center in Brooklyn. We'll get down and dirty, crawling through mud, climbings walls and nets, tire running, and tackling water slides—all in support of our 2015–16 youth programs.

What You Can Do

Sponsor a member of our running team! Last year's sponsorships allowed With Food in Mind to reach more children than ever before, as well as to launch a new food justice program for teenage artists. Your generous and fully tax-deductible donations will help us pay teaching artists, purchase program materials, and keep our drop-in workshops free to children and families in low-income neighborhoods. Even a small contribution has big impact.

  • $20 provides English- and Spanish-language activity sheets for six workshops.
  • $25 provides fruit and seltzer for one Fruity Pop workshop.
  • $50 covers one week of transportation for ten teens.
  • $100 covers all of the ingredients and art supplies for one Fruity Pop workshop.
  • $250 covers the honorarium for two teaching artists.
  • $400 funds an entire three-hour Fruity Pop workshop.
Sponsor a With Food in Mind team member and help us expand the reach of our art and food education programs!

When we got back I donated 4 bikes. I do plan on getting 4 more bikes to replace them. Im not going to buy them new or anything like that. Just going to bike 4-6 more used good working beach cruisers from craigslist. 
If you feel like donating then do it as it would really help. I'm also going to be putting away some money every time i pedicab to replace them. Either way there will be bikes at the next burn.

story:
My Story:

This project is a return to my childhood home, an abandoned schoolhouse, to create art from the things my mother hoarded over the years and explore questions she can no longer answer in her current mental state. This is a journey of self-discovery. This is my story:

When I was 11, my parents moved our family to an abandoned school building in rural Colorado. I lived there for 6 years, without plumbing, central heat, or full electricity. Isolated and disconnected from a community, my mother's hoarding took over a lot of the space. It was a strange and challenging place to grow up. My parents have since moved to the closest town, 40 minutes away, leaving the school house abandoned once again. Two years ago, my mother was in a serious bike accident, suffering severe brain damage. I started taking trips back home to help my father care for my mother. In revisiting my past, I realized there was much that was unresolved within me that I had been avoiding.

Last summer I decided to go back to this building after a decade away, to live and work there alone, creating art pieces from materials I found in the building. Living in isolation (no internet or cell phone) and surrounded by my memories and family history, I used the experience of transforming physical materials as a way to transform my relationship to my story. With my mother's damaged mind, I am not able to communicate and connect with her as I did before. This project is also a way for me to learn about and connect to her through the lifetime of things she has held onto, and a way to use my challenges as fuel to focus on and create beauty and love.

I am eager to get back to Colorado and continue this series of work with the intention of putting together a solo show in NYC, owning and sharing my story with others. This is my most vulnerable and authentic work to date.

How funds will be used:

To continue making this body of work, I need help with funding this project and supporting my family.

Expenses:

  • Packaging/shipping of finished pieces to NYC in November: $3000
  • Gallery Space rental: $500/dayx5 days: $2500
  • Travel: Thatcher trip (September-October) - air fare, cars, and gas: $800
  • Basic art supplies (tarps/adhesive/tools/resin/wood): $500
  • Temporary storage for pieces before show in NYC: $200

If I surpass my campaign goal, additional funds will go towards stretch goals:

  • Care for my mother for 4 days (so my father can see the show in NYC): $1200
  • Extended dates for exhibition: $500/day
  • Longer care for my mother: $300/day

Perks:

I'm offering some great perks as incentive to those who can donate

* VIP tickets to the exhibition in November. This VIP showing will be a sneak peak of the finished show in NYC, with drinks, music, and great company.

* Exclusive access to artist's web blog, with behind the scenes info, images, and video of my life in Thatcher and my process for this project. A great perk for anyone interested in knowing more about this journey.

* Prints showcasing the natural beauty and golden light of Thatcher, with multiple sizing and framing options.  See options here

* Original art pieces from this project. I am making available many works of art from this Thatcher series as a pre-sale to the final exhibition in NYC. They are available for pick up after the show, or can be shipped domestically at an additional cost. Note that many of the pieces are large and heavy. More images here

What this project explores:

This project is for everyone who has felt shameful or alone. For many years I was ashamed of where I am from, and I felt very much alone in what I was going through. It takes courage to dig into unpleasant memories and expose our wounds to the light, but it's the only way to come to a complete healing. I'm using this project as a way to connect with others, to share in our unique human experiences. I hope to inspire you to share your stories and shed light on what has been kept in the dark.  With this project, my relationship to my artistic process and my self continues to transform in ways I never imagined.

This work is about the human experience: life/death, light/dark, creation/destruction, and order/chaos being part of the same process. I'm exploring what comes up in space, silence, and isolation, what we fill our spaces with, what happens when these things and spaces deteriorate, making use of the unused, and the energy that objects take on as we keep them in our lives.  It is my hope that people take away from this project the importance of shedding light on difficult experiences, accepting all parts of our selves, and sharing our stories. What makes us unique makes us beautiful.

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you want to be a part of this journey with me, but cannot contribute financially, please share this campaign on social media and in your networks. I'm also open to other ideas about ways to support this project, showing it in NYC, or direct ways to help my family.

Feel free to email me with other ideas, questions, or your own inspiring story of self-acceptance: stephlcalvert@gmail.com

You can also follow me on Instagram or Twitter

Thank you for your support!

Special thanks to my dearest family who continues to support my creative pursuits and inspires my path of love, Osher Assouline, who has been invaluable in helping me through this process, and to Max Chen, my talented video editor.

story:
About ArtsFest

Allentown ArtsFest was created in 2014 as an alternative to the modern art festival. The event strives to fill in gaps frequently left by festival programming. Many talented artists miss out on their chance to get involved in such an event due to being too different or not fitting a mold. ArtsFest has no mold, it’s an event that is always searching for something people have rarely seen. 

The mission of ArtsFest is to challenge not only ‘what is art?’ but also what art can be. For this reason, ArtsFest covers a wide variety of mediums, such as: graffiti, stand-up comedy, technology, upcylcing, assemblage sculpture, dance, film, theater, spoken word, and a vast range of musical genres. The festival is run solely by volunteers and will always be FREE for everyone, of all ages. 

2014 saw nearly 6,000 guests in attendance and 2015 is expected to draw more than 10,000! 


We Want YOU To Sponsor ArtsFest! 

The festival does not currently have any major corporate sponsorships. It is too unique and too new of an event for many larger companies to take a gamble on. And at the same time, we will only work with companies & organizations that reflect the mission and idea behind ArtsFest. We won't take money from just any company and slap their logo on our brand. ArtsFest is important to us, we want it to stay pure and will not sacrifice our morals for funding! 

We are more interested in working with small businesses and individuals as sponsors. It gives those involved a feeling of ownership in the event and it builds on the community aspect that the organization was founded on. 

We'd rather have small sponsors who support what we do and want to be on the front lines with us, much more so than some faceless company who wants to promote their new product! 

So that means we need YOU to step up and help ensure ArtsFest keeps going for many years to come! 

Why Are Sponsorships Important? 

The only way funding comes in for ArtsFest is through vendor booths, grants, donations & sponsorships. 

We've already covered the sponsorship category... and we're a very new Non-Profit (March 2015), which hasn't given us enough time to receive grant money. So the only other funding that comes through for us is from vendor booths and donations. 

Our vendor booths are VERY reasonably priced, if you compare them to other festivals of this size or smaller, they are actually pretty cheap. We do this to help ensure that our vendors make money off of the event. This means the vendor booths are only able to cover a small percentage of the total cost of the festival. 

Donations come in many forms; this could mean a company donates use of equipment instead of having to outright pay for it, that cost would be calculated and they would become a sponsor at that price range. Since we're a Non-Profit, all financial support, regardless of where it's from, is a donation. Which makes the contributor a donor. This is how many companies such as PBS or NPR stick around. 

We've had a handful of donations, but nothing to put a dent in the actual cost of the festival. Which again, leaves the best avenue for covering the rest of the funds in the hands of the sponsors! 

The only other funding that comes through for us is that we actually handle the sales of all alcohol. Being a non-profit, we are able to apply for a limited liquor license through the Liquor Control Board and sell alcohol legally. But this means more costs, much more. We have to buy all of the alcohol up front, and as last year proved, that can be a costly venture. Because of the long rainy day last year, not enough people bought the amount of beer needed to cover expenses and it only put us FURTHER in the hole! 

We will be selling delicious craft beers again this year from Sly Fox, Hijinx, The Other Farm, Saucony Creek, Funk Brewing & newcomer Soul Brewing. Our goal is to go INTO ArtsFest breaking even so that any profit will fund future gallery programs. 

The Cost of Doing Business

Now that we've covered how the festival relies on paying its bills, one thing that hasn't been covered is the COST of running a festival such as this. 

For those who haven't been involved in organizing outdoor events, there are A LOT of expenses that you would never expect to have to pay. 

  • Fencing in the entire festival ($4,300)
  • Tents, tables & chairs ($2,500)
  • Generators & Lights ($2,500)
  • Stage, stage equipment, backline & sound team ($4,300)
  • Portable restrooms & hand washing stations ($2,800)
  • Allentown Police Department, EMT, Fire Police & Overnight Security ($6,000)
  • Insurance ($3,000)
  • Water, Dumpsters & Trash Removal ($1,000)
  • Clean Team ($900)
  • Permits/Fees/Licenses ($500)
  • Advertising/Merch ($2,500)
  • Cups & Beverages/Beer ($5,000)
TOTAL = $35,300

And that's not even ALL of the expenses. Those are rough estimates of some of the things we had to pay for, with probably another $4,000-5,000 in addition to that. Which means ArtsFest costs about $40,000 to put on! 

Once you start to break it down, even $8,000 doesn't go a long way. 

In 2014, the festival made nearly $30k LESS than what the bills added up to. Which meant the Alternative Gallery spent the better part of the year paying off those expenses out of pocket. That's no small amount of money either, imagine what programs we could have created or what else we could have used that money for.

Our goal for 2015 is to go into ArtsFest breaking even, so for the next year, we can fund MANY more programs. 

ALL funding obtained through this fundraiser will cover some of our larger expenses such as fencing & staging. 

What's In It For Me? 

Aside from that awesome fuzzy feeling you get all over from doing a good thing and supporting a community event, there are some really great perks for becoming an individual sponsor of ArtsFest. 

We've taken the time to see what people like to take home with them from festivals, art shows, looked through cool perks in other campaigns, and overall just tried to avoid giving away run of the mill items. 

NOTE: We WILL ship International, please message us with your location to determine shipping rate.

Obviously one of the things people love the most are shirts. Shirts can be a way to promote something you love or support, they can give you a clear voice without having to say a word, or even offer insight into what kind of stuff you like. 

So this year we have 3 different shirts for ArtsFest! 

Our first shirt is the ArtsFest Logo Shirt. This is a 1-color screen print on a cotton shirt. We had these last year and they've become a crowd favorite so we brought it back! IMPORTANT: Make sure you note what size shirt you need and select either White or Black shirt.


Our second shirt is the ArtsFest 2015 Shirt. This is a 1-color screen print on a cotton shirt. IMPORTANT: Make sure you note what size shirt you need and select from the following color shirts: Red, Green, Yellow or Blue. 


Finally, we have the big daddy of the shirts, the FULL COLOR ArtsFest 2015 shirt! The additional colors makes this much more difficult to make and more expensive! 

These are limited edition so get yours while you can! 

Again, please note what SIZE you need. These shirts will only be printed on white. 

Next we have the poster for ArtsFest 2015 by artist Steven Leibensperger.

The $10 level will get you a regular 11x17 poster print.

The $100 level will get you a 18x24 beautiful EXCLUSIVE velvet poster print.

And the $250 level will get you a hand signed & numbered Limited Edition Full Color Screen Printed Poster! 

And for those of you unfamiliar with the Alternative Gallery, the organization that hosts ArtsFest, we do this type of stuff all year long! 

The Alternative Gallery is a Non-Profit (501-c3) organization founded in 2012 in Allentown, PA. The mission of the gallery is to strengthen communities through art and education. The Alternative Gallery aims to create a space that is open and welcoming to all, and involves those who wouldn’t typically enter an art gallery. Located in the Cigar Factory, the Alternative Gallery hosts hundreds of events a year including live music, a weekly open mic, dance competitions, art classes, screenings, workshops, art exhibits & more. 

Many of the events the Alternative Gallery hosts are free, but there are also a LOT of other events that are pay at the door. This is how we help to cover the expenses of running events and also help to pay the performers & artists who take part in these events. 
Starting at the $50 level, you can earn free entry into either events OR classes at the Alternative Gallery! 


Other Ways You Can Help

We know not everyone can spare the extra change to help support our cause, and that's ok! There are plenty of other ways you can pitch in and help us out! 

Most importantly, would be sharing this campaign and letting people know what we're doing. We want to keep ArtsFest as grassroots as possible and word of mouth is as grassroots as it gets! 

You can also invite people to attend ArtsFest when it happens, from Sep. 11-13th. It is after all a FREE event! 

https://www.facebook.com/events/1601064986812559/

And of course, ArtsFest is only able to happen at all because of the amazing team of volunteers we have running it. Literally every single person from the Event Coordinator to a 1-shift volunteer does this solely for the support of the cause. 

You can easily sign-up to volunteer by following this link: 

http://www.signupgenius.com/go/10c054baaaa2aaaf...

We thank you for even taking the time to read this far, you must REALLY love the arts! 

Thank you all and we hope to see you at ArtsFest 2015! 

Sincerely,

The ArtsFest 2015 Crew

The festival does not currently have any major corporate sponsorships. It is too unique and too new of an event for many larger companies to take a gamble on. And at the same time, we will only work with companies & organizations that reflect the mission and idea behind ArtsFest. We won't take money from just any company and slap their logo on our brand. ArtsFest is important to us, we want it to stay pure and will not sacrifice our morals for funding! 

We are more interested in working with small businesses and individuals as sponsors. It gives those involved a feeling of ownership in the event and it builds on the community aspect that the organization was founded on. 

We'd rather have small sponsors who support what we do and want to be on the front lines with us, much more so than some faceless company who wants to promote their new product! 

So that means we need YOU to step up and help ensure ArtsFest keeps going for many years to come! 


Why Are Sponsorships Important? 
 The only way funding comes in for ArtsFest is through vendor booths, grants, donations & sponsorships. 
We've already covered the sponsorship category... and we're a very new Non-Profit (March 2015), which hasn't given us enough time to receive grant money. So the only other funding that comes through for us is from vendor booths and donations. 
Our vendor booths are VERY reasonably priced, if you compare them to other festivals of this size or smaller, they are actually pretty cheap. We do this to help ensure that our vendors make money off of the event. This means the vendor booths are only able to cover a small percentage of the total cost of the festival. 
Donations come in many forms; this could mean a company donates use of equipment instead of having to outright pay for it, that cost would be calculated and they would become a sponsor at that price range. Since we're a Non-Profit, all financial support, regardless of where it's from, is a donation. Which makes the contributor a donor. This is how many companies such as PBS or NPR stick around. 
We've had a handful of donations, but nothing to put a dent in the actual cost of the festival. Which again, leaves the best avenue for covering the rest of the funds in the hands of the sponsors! 
The only other funding that comes through for us is that we actually handle the sales of all alcohol. Being a non-profit, we are able to apply for a limited liquor license through the Liquor Control Board and sell alcohol legally. But this means more costs, much more. We have to buy all of the alcohol up front, and as last year proved, that can be a costly venture. Because of the long rainy day last year, not enough people bought the amount of beer needed to cover expenses and it only put us FURTHER in the hole! 
We will be selling delicious craft beers again this year from Sly Fox, Hijinx,
The Other Farm, Saucony Creek, Funk Brewing & newcomer Soul Brewing. Our goal is to go INTO ArtsFest breaking even so that any profit will fund future gallery programs. 
    The Cost of Doing Business Now that we've covered how the festival relies on paying its bills, one thing that hasn't been covered is the COST of running a festival such as this. 
For those who haven't been involved in organizing outdoor events, there are A LOT of expenses that you would never expect to have to pay. 


Fencing in the entire festival ($4,300)
Tents, tables & chairs ($2,500)
Generators & Lights ($2,500)
Stage, stage equipment, backline & sound team ($4,300)
Portable restrooms & hand washing stations ($2,800)
Allentown Police Department, EMT, Fire Police & Overnight Security ($6,000)
Insurance ($3,000)
Water, Dumpsters & Trash Removal ($1,000)
Clean Team ($900)
Permits/Fees/Licenses ($500)
Advertising/Merch ($2,500)
Cups & Beverages/Beer ($5,000)

TOTAL = $35,300

And that's not even ALL of the expenses. Those are rough estimates of some of the things we had to pay for, with probably another $4,000-5,000 in addition to that. Which means ArtsFest costs about $40,000 to put on! 

Once you start to break it down, even $8,000 doesn't go a long way. 

In 2014, the festival made nearly $30k LESS than what the bills added up to. Which meant the Alternative Gallery spent the better part of the year paying off those expenses out of pocket. That's no small amount of money either, imagine what programs we could have created or what else we could have used that money for.

Our goal for 2015 is to go into ArtsFest breaking even, so for the next year, we can fund MANY more programs. 

ALL funding obtained through this fundraiser will cover some of our larger expenses such as fencing & staging. 


What's In It For Me? 
Aside from that awesome fuzzy feeling you get all over from doing a good thing and supporting a community event, there are some really great perks for becoming an individual sponsor of ArtsFest. 

We've taken the time to see what people like to take home with them from festivals, art shows, looked through cool perks in other campaigns, and overall just tried to avoid giving away run of the mill items. 


NOTE: We WILL ship International, please message us with your location to determine shipping rate.

Obviously one of the things people love the most are shirts. Shirts can be a way to promote something you love or support, they can give you a clear voice without having to say a word, or even offer insight into what kind of stuff you like. 


So this year we have 3 different shirts for ArtsFest! 

Our first shirt is the ArtsFest Logo Shirt. This is a 1-color screen print on a cotton shirt. We had these last year and they've become a crowd favorite so we brought it back! IMPORTANT: Make sure you note what size shirt you need and select either White or Black shirt.






Our second shirt is the ArtsFest 2015 Shirt. This is a 1-color screen print on a cotton shirt. IMPORTANT: Make sure you note what size shirt you need and select from the following color shirts: Red, Green, Yellow or Blue. 




Finally, we have the big daddy of the shirts, the FULL COLOR ArtsFest 2015 shirt! The additional colors makes this much more difficult to make and more expensive! 

These are limited edition so get yours while you can! 

Again, please note what SIZE you need. These shirts will only be printed on white. 





Next we have the poster for ArtsFest 2015 by artist Steven Leibensperger.
The $10 level will get you a regular 11x17 poster print.
The $100 level will get you a 18x24 beautiful EXCLUSIVE velvet poster print.
And the $250 level will get you a hand signed & numbered Limited Edition Full Color Screen Printed Poster! 


And for those of you unfamiliar with the Alternative Gallery, the organization that hosts ArtsFest, we do this type of stuff all year long! 


The Alternative Gallery is a Non-Profit (501-c3)
organization founded in 2012 in Allentown, PA. The mission of the gallery is to
strengthen communities through art and education. The Alternative Gallery aims
to create a space that is open and welcoming to all, and involves those who
wouldn’t typically enter an art gallery. Located in the Cigar Factory, the
Alternative Gallery hosts hundreds of events a year including live music, a
weekly open mic, dance competitions, art classes, screenings, workshops, art
exhibits & more. 

Many of the events the Alternative Gallery hosts are free, but there are also a LOT of other events that are pay at the door. This is how we help to cover the expenses of running events and also help to pay the performers & artists who take part in these events. 
Starting at the $50 level, you can earn free entry into either events OR classes at the Alternative Gallery! 


Other Ways You Can Help

 We know not everyone can spare the extra change to help support our cause, and that's ok! There are plenty of other ways you can pitch in and help us out! 
Most importantly, would be sharing this campaign and letting people know what we're doing. We want to keep ArtsFest as grassroots as possible and word of mouth is as grassroots as it gets! 
You can also invite people to attend ArtsFest when it happens, from Sep. 11-13th. It is after all a FREE event! 
https://www.facebook.com/events/1601064986812559/
And of course, ArtsFest is only able to happen at all because of the amazing team of volunteers we have running it. Literally every single person from the Event Coordinator to a 1-shift volunteer does this solely for the support of the cause. 
You can easily sign-up to volunteer by following this link: 
http://www.signupgenius.com/go/10c054baaaa2aaaf...
We thank you for even taking the time to read this far, you must REALLY love the arts! 
Thank you all and we hope to see you at ArtsFest 2015! 
Sincerely,
The ArtsFest 2015 Crew

story:
Who I am

My name is Kathrine Avraam. I graduated from the Department of Audio & Visual Arts at Ionian University in 2014 and I am looking forward to start the coming academic year my Master at EESI at Angoulême in the field of Bande Dessinée.


What is this project?

This Project is my first attempt to crowdfund my work, as another way to support myself financially. The goal is a fair amount of money to compensate my efforts giving birth to this digital book; Le Petit Chaperon Rouge de Charles Perrault, while at the same time a hope to produce a limited amount of hard copies.
So love me and chip in!

The Genesis
This Project started on the occasion of a 3day Workshop in Children's Book Illustration but soon it became a personal goal. 

Conceptual Approach
The symbolism of the heroin as a drop of blood (Menstruation) while a forest of fingerprints denotes the formation of her identity was my first idea of this book, but was quickly abandoned for being "too adult" (see Images in Gallery).

From then on I chose the deduction to the Basic Shapes and Colors: the Red Circle for the Heroine, symbol of her journey to womanhood and a friendly color loved by many, the Yellow Square and the enclosed Curves for the Granny, metaphor of her protective nature, that never reaches the girl and the Blue Triangle for the Wolf, the cold-blooded beast that acts upon its instincts.

The funny thing is, although I had decided on this semiology rather easily, I ended up designing a much more lovable wolf than the heroin herself. For that I blame me and my gluttonous nature! ^_^

Concerning the framing and the style of depiction, I started with a much more discriptive approach that gradually turned into abstraction and plain form and color dynamism, only to find a merge between the two in the final image- or at least that's what I strived for). 



Digital Publishing and my moral Code

The Book is and will remain free for everyone interested to take a look. It is accessible online here and you are encouraged-if not begged- to share it with your children, your nephews, your students, your art-lover friends, your inner child  etc. 

The content of Le Petit Chaperon Rouge de Charles Perrault  belongs to the public domain and as such it has no legal bounds corcerning its republication. The same applies at the font used, the use of which is decalred open even for commercial use. Therefore, the above creation does not violate other people's rights nor their labor.


Why in French?

As stated above, The content of Le Petit Chaperon Rouge de Charles Perrault belongs to the public domain and given the fact that his author is french, well, you can guess the rest...

If you do  however know an English version that is Royalty-free, I would be happy to to publish a second version of the current book. 


Risks & Challenges

As everything in life, the risk is the probable failure of this cause, thus leaving you with a digital book and me empty-handed, but that is a risk I am more than willing to take!

Spread the word!

Thank you,
Gros Bisous! 

Le "qui suis-je"

Je m'appelle Kathrine Avraam. J'ai gradué le Département d'Arts Audiovisuels d'Université Ionienne en 2014 et J'ai hâte de commencer l'année académique suivante ma formation au niveau Master à EESI, Angoulême à la filière de Bande Dessinée. 


C'est quoi ce projet?

C’est ma première tentative de crowdfund mon travail, pour que je puisse me supporter financement d’une autre manière. La cible est un juste somme d’argent pour compenser mes efforts de donner naissance à ce Livre Numerique; Le Petit Chaperon Rouge de Charles Perrault, quand en même temps pour donner l’espoir d’une production limitée des copies papier.


La Naissance

Ce Projet a commencé à l’occasion d’un atelier d’illustration de livres pour les enfants durant 3 jours, mais éventuellement il était devenu un but personnel. 

Approche Conceptuelle

Le symbolisme de l’héroïne comme une goutte de sang (Menstruation) pendant une forêt d’empreintes dénote la formation de sa propre identité était ma première idée de ce livre, laquelle était rapidement abandonnée en étant « si adulte » (voir la Galerie Photo).

Depuis ce moment-là, j’ai choisis la déduction au Formes et Couleurs Basiques; le Cercle Rouge pour l’héroïne, symbole de son voyage à la féminité ainsi qu’un couleur bien-aimé par tous, le Carré Jaune et les Courbes y fermées pour la Grand-Mère, une métaphore de sa nature protective mais qui n’arrive jamais à sa petite-fille et finalement le Triangle Blue pour le Loup, la bête de sang-froid qui agit sur ses instincts.

Le plus drôle est le fait que bien que j’aie décidé sur cette Sémiologie assez facilement, J'ai fini par désigner un beaucoup plus agréable et aimable loup. 
Ça, c’est de ma faute et celle de ma nature gourmande! ^_^

En ce qui concerne le cadrage et le style de représentation, j’ai commencé par une approche plus descriptive qui se transforme graduellement en abstractive, avec des formes et des couleurs plein de dynamisme et qui conclut au mélange de ceux deux à l’image finale- ou pour moins celui-ci était mon but.



Publication Numérique et mon Code Moral

Ce Livre Numérique est et restera gratuit pour tout le monde intéressé de jeter un coup d'œil. Il est accessible en ligne ici et vous êtes encouragés- ou bien suppliés- de le partager avec vos enfants, nos nièces et neveux, vos élèves, vos  amis amateurs d’art, votre enfant intérieur etc.

Le contenu de Le Petit Chaperon Rouge de Charles Perrault est une œuvre appartenant au domaine public et comme un tel il n’y a aucune limite légale concernant sa reproduction. De la même manière, la police de caractères utilisée est ouverte même pour l’usage commercial. Par conséquent, la création au-dessous ne viole pas les droits de personne ni leur travaille personnelle.


Pourquoi en français?

Comme indiqué ci-dessus, le contenue de Le Petit Chaperon Rouge de Charles Perrault appartient au domaine public et étant donné que l’auteur est français, bah voilà, on peut imaginer le reste…  


Risques et Défis

Comme tout dans la vie, le risque est un probable échec de cette opération qui vous offrira gratuitement un e-book et quant à moi les mains vides, mais c’est un risque que j’aimerais bien prendre!

Faites passer le mot !


Merci et
Gros Bisous!

story:
The Skinny~
  • Name:  Amanda Stirn a/k/a MiMi Stirn Artist, also known as The Owl Chick
  • Passion: Painting followed by guitar, piano, cooking, and paddleboarding
  • Goal:  Raise funds for new tent and 3 art shows, ultimately saving up to open up a different kind of rocking  "ART GALLERY" within the next 3 years. 
  • Art Medium this campaign is supporting - 2D Mixed Media Art
  • Why A Campaign #1: The 2D Media Art has taken off and I have been selected to show all the new 2D work - and I need a replacement tent

  • Why #2:  My tent, a loaner from a fellow artist (I am so sorry Claude and Debbie), along with all of my art walls were destroyed this summer during a huge, hurricane gust wind storm at an art show.  I am now up for 3 shows and need a new tent, and just as important, stock up the now growing popular MiMi's 2D Mixed Media collection, thus 20 paintings in 10 weeks for 3 shows


This campaign is critical to my success at my upcoming shows. I have been a fine art and musician for most of my life, let's age me and just say 30+ years. Yup, That's right, I started piano at 4 and drawing in my teens.   I have graduated to fine art showings recently, which means my display is critical to acceptance, and in some cases will enable me to compete for prize money to grow my art collection.  The long-term goal is to own a gallery to support other emerging artists in a few years, but I have to pay my dues and my roots start at shows, thus this fundraiser.
This is an all or none campaign and all contributions have a perk.

"Every contribution makes a difference, plus the perks are awesome.  I love sharing my passion for the arts with my fans, perks are a way of saying thank you and paying it forward."

You can read more about me, my artist statement, bio, etc. at the bottom of the page.  

What MiMi Needs & What You Get

For the record, I am invested into my art.  In the span of the past 2-years since officially opening as an artist in business, my investment to date is towering over $6,000. Yes, Ouch! But, fans love the work, I am being accepted into shows. Online art is very, very , hard to sale. Showing in person is the ticket, this is where the tire meets the road.  I need to show more in order to get out of this emerging artist funk, because I am not really emerging if you count the past 30 years of my artistic life.
 
What I need to keep the momentum going...
  • Replacement Tent, Mesh Walls, Hooks, Shipping - $2,000
  • Show Fees (just the next 3) $1,000
  • Remaining 2-D Art Supplies (this is the 20 in 10) $500
  • Show Supplies $500
  • Travel and Lodging $500
OK -  Now... The PERKS!  They ROCK!
I have perks for everyone from the $5 level to the $1,000 level... Below are pictures the perks and you can read more in the actual "Perk" section.  I will be posting weekly video snip its of progress on the creation of the 20 in 10 collection during this campaign. 
Here are original paintings at the $150 level - 1 of each available, all 20 x 20 on gallery wrapped canvas

Here are original paintings at the $125 level - 1 of each available, all on gallery wrapped canvas

  • NOTE: Below are examples and for phone cases, necklaces, totes, and posters, I will contact you so you can select the art you want on the perk.  Anything with the logo i.e. shirts, hot sauce, and stickers, those are as is.  Original painting perks come with other perks - described in the Perks section.
  • iPhone Cases Available include: iPhone 6, 6Plus, 5S, 5C, 5, 4s and 4
  • Samsung phone cases include: Galaxy S6, S5, and S4

The originals in the higher price range are all on gallery wrapped canvas and will come with some of the smaller perks as well.  If you want to see bigger pictures, you can check them out on my website www.mimistirnart.com and there is a video for the set of six under the $600 perk on YouTube https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z8uMu8PqlDc


The Impact

Please help me reach my goal so I can make not only make the next 3 shows happen, but give me the boost so I can be successful now by selling the art I love, and also reserving money earned from shows to eventually open a gallery to support those artists out there who need help - seriously this goal is part of a bigger dream - the grand goal, long-term, is opening doors for great artist who need a helping hand in getting their work shown less the bureaucratic garbage that stifles creativity for emerging artists. I would like to step away from traditional gallery rules and re-write the book.

Successes to date include:
  • Officially in business as an artist June 2013
  • Cape Coral Festival of the Arts January 2014
  • 1st Place in Fine Art America Best Abstract Competition September 2014
  • 1st Place in Fine Art America Best Work of Art to Support Breast Cancer Awareness October 2014
  • Miss Kim's Recital (Art demo and class) at Wild Child Art Gallery, May 2015
  • Sarasota Art Festival June 2015
  • Monthly Exhibition, first Friday's Downtown Fort Myers Art Walk
  • Upcoming - Juried into Artnado, West Palm Beach November 2015
  • Art on Exhibit at von Liebig Art Center in Naples Sept - Oct 2015
  • Facebook Fans: 4,400 and growing

Risks & Challenges

  • The main hurdle at this point is by large and obviously, if I don't raise the $4,000 needed, I go  $10,000 out of pocket, in debt or alternately not show, which means not grow.
  • I know I can overcome the challenges with funding, but without funding, well I have to make a choice - should I show this year, or  save up over the next 12-months, and risk loosing the momentum I have gained. So after much thought here is how I think. As a business analyst and prior business owner of two other businesses, risks are inherent of business, and through the years as a business owner and consultant for other businesses, calculated risks are better than taking no risk at all - so yes, I will probably go for it and die trying - shows equal sales, I have skin in the game, I am not stopping now.

About Me  - MiMi Stirn

No this is not another boring resume, but it is a long-winded artist statement and bio, just so you know... I am legit...

Statement: My favorite art tools are knives. They are unforgiven yet clear and finite when used. Working within the acrylic family is fun, but working with modeling paste is where the art begins; free form and each application remind me of swimming. What I love best about creating art is the freedom of expression without fear of consequence. When I am able to say a work has turned out well, is actually the moment when I can return to the art over the course of several days and repeatedly be transported into the picture itself.

The pattern or usual styles I use are centered on both working with circular and straight line motions while respecting Fibonacci sequences in the placement of each element; however, bright light, layers of color, and use of metallic pigments are my standard. What I do differently from what I was taught is dirty brushing. My brushes & knives during the painting process are usually lapped with new colors without actually washing them; I love the mystery of the blends, and the picture always turns out beautiful. My favorite color on the spectrum is Prussian blue, and is usually incorporated in to my skies, water scenes, and shadowing.

Short Bio: My early works began in the late 80’s, mainly sketches using coal and colored pencils.  In 1996 I began working with oils and acrylics in a folk art style with subjects including animal miniatures, farms, flowers, trees, and field animals.  I completed several full-length wall murals during this time. In 2010, my husband and I moved to Cape Coral Florida from Washington State.  I was inspired to change my artistic styling from folk art to abstract works with focus on ample, bold colors.  The beautiful sunrise, sunsets, and of course, the cute burrowing owls, native to our area, opened the door rekindle my passion for painting and expand my art skills.  Additional inspiration comes from years of traveling as a military brat and spouse.  I have been blessed to see the beautiful landscapes and wildlife from growing-up in Guam, Louisiana, Germany, New Mexico, and Washington. 


My focus these past 5-years has been abstract color techniques including blending, staining, resin pours, and subtraction processes.  All artwork is on gallery wrapped canvas, ranging from 10” X 10” up to 60” x 60”.

I have my degree in Business Administration, am a Florida State Certified Business Consultant, and a Certified Marketing Strategist through Cornell University. My husband and I have two grown sons and are looking forward to grandchildren and our exciting new life in Florida. I also am an avid paddle boarder, acoustic guitarist and pianist, and enjoy cooking. Mastering the art of color and nature is my first passion and I am elated to share my artwork with you.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, here is how you can help:

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about the campaign.
  • Share with your friends via email and social media
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools and blast on social media!

And..that's about it - Thank you all for supporting the arts!
story_txt:
The Skinny~  Name:  Amanda Stirn a/k/a MiMi Stirn Artist, also known as The Owl Chick
Passion: Painting followed by guitar, piano, cooking, and paddleboarding 

Goal:  Raise funds for new tent and 3 art shows, ultimately saving up to open up a different kind of rocking  "ART GALLERY" within the next 3 years.  

Art Medium this campaign is supporting - 2D Mixed Media Art
Why A Campaign #1: The 2D Media Art has taken off and I have been selected to show all the new 2D work - and I need a replacement tent


Why #2:  My tent, a loaner from a fellow artist (I am so sorry Claude and Debbie), along with all of my art walls were destroyed this summer during a huge, hurricane gust wind storm at an art show.  I am now up for 3 shows and need a new tent, and just as important, stock up the now growing popular MiMi's 2D Mixed Media collection, thus 20 paintings in 10 weeks for 3 shows




This campaign is critical to my success at my upcoming shows. I have been a fine art and musician for most of my life, let's age me and just say 30+ years. Yup, That's right, I started piano at 4 and drawing in my teens.   I have graduated to fine art showings recently, which means my display is critical to acceptance, and in some cases will enable me to compete for prize money to grow my art collection.  The long-term goal is to own a gallery to support other emerging artists in a few years, but I have to pay my dues and my roots start at shows, thus this fundraiser. This is an all or none campaign and all contributions have a perk."Every contribution makes a difference, plus the perks are awesome.  I love sharing my passion for the arts with my fans, perks are a way of saying thank you and paying it forward." You can read more about me, my artist statement, bio, etc. at the bottom of the page.       What MiMi Needs & What You Get  For the record, I am invested into my art.  In the span of the past 2-years since officially opening as an artist in business, my investment to date is towering over $6,000. Yes, Ouch! But, fans love the work, I am being accepted into shows. Online art is very, very , hard to sale. Showing in person is the ticket, this is where the tire meets the road.  I need to show more in order to get out of this emerging artist funk, because I am not really emerging if you count the past 30 years of my artistic life.   What I need to keep the momentum going...
Replacement Tent, Mesh Walls, Hooks, Shipping - $2,000 

Show Fees (just the next 3) $1,000

Remaining 2-D Art Supplies (this is the 20 in 10) $500

Show Supplies $500

Travel and Lodging $500
 
OK -  Now... The PERKS!  They ROCK! I have perks for everyone from the $5 level to the $1,000 level... Below are pictures the perks and you can read more in the actual "Perk" section.  I will be posting weekly video snip its of progress on the creation of the 20 in 10 collection during this campaign.  Here are original paintings at the $150 level - 1 of each available, all 20 x 20 on gallery wrapped canvas

Here are original paintings at the $125 level - 1 of each available, all on gallery wrapped canvas 

NOTE: Below are examples and for phone cases, necklaces, totes, and 
posters, I will contact you so you can select the art you want on the 
perk.  Anything with the logo i.e. shirts, hot sauce, and stickers, 
those are as is.  Original painting perks come with other perks - 
described in the Perks section.
iPhone Cases Available include: iPhone 6, 6Plus, 5S, 5C, 5,
4s and 4
Samsung phone cases include: Galaxy S6, S5, and S4


The originals in the higher price range are all on gallery wrapped canvas and will come with some of the smaller perks as well.  If you want to see bigger pictures, you can check them out on my website www.mimistirnart.com and there is a video for the set of six under the $600 perk on YouTube https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z8uMu8PqlDc



The Impact


Please help me reach my goal so I can make not only
make the next 3 shows happen, but give me the boost so I can be successful now
by selling the art I love, and also reserving money earned from shows to
eventually open a gallery to support those artists out there who need help -
seriously this goal is part of a bigger dream - the grand goal, long-term, is
opening doors for great artist who need a helping hand in getting their work shown
less the bureaucratic garbage that stifles creativity for emerging artists. I
would like to step away from traditional gallery rules and re-write the book.Successes to date include:
Officially in business as an artist June 2013
Cape Coral Festival of the Arts January 2014

1st Place in Fine Art America Best Abstract Competition September 2014
1st Place in Fine Art America Best Work of Art to Support Breast Cancer Awareness October 2014
Miss Kim's Recital (Art demo and class) at Wild Child Art Gallery, May 2015
Sarasota Art Festival June 2015
Monthly Exhibition, first Friday's Downtown Fort Myers Art Walk

Upcoming - Juried into Artnado, West Palm Beach November 2015
Art on Exhibit at von Liebig Art Center in Naples Sept - Oct 2015

Facebook Fans: 4,400 and growing
    Risks & Challenges    The main hurdle at this point is by large and obviously, if I don't raise the $4,000 needed, I go  $10,000 out of pocket, in debt or alternately not show, which means not grow. 

I know I can overcome the challenges with funding, but without funding, well I have to make a choice - should I show this year, or  save up over the next 12-months, and risk loosing the momentum I have gained. So after much thought here is how I think. As a business analyst and prior business owner of two other businesses, risks are inherent of business, and through the years as a business owner and consultant for other businesses, calculated risks are better than taking no risk at all - so yes, I will probably go for it and die trying - shows equal sales, I have skin in the game, I am not stopping now. 

   About Me  - MiMi Stirn
No this is not another boring resume, but it is a long-winded artist statement and bio, just so you know... I am legit...




Statement: My favorite art tools are knives. They are unforgiven yet clear and 
finite when used. Working within the acrylic family is fun, but working 
with modeling paste is where the art begins; free form and each 
application remind me of swimming. What I love best about creating art 
is the freedom of expression without fear of consequence. When I am able
 to say a work has turned out well, is actually the moment when I can 
return to the art over the course of several days and repeatedly be 
transported into the picture itself.
The pattern or usual styles I use are centered on both working with 
circular and straight line motions while respecting Fibonacci sequences 
in the placement of each element; however, bright light, layers of 
color, and use of metallic pigments are my standard. What I do 
differently from what I was taught is dirty brushing. My brushes & 
knives during the painting process are usually lapped with new colors 
without actually washing them; I love the mystery of the blends, and the
 picture always turns out beautiful. My favorite color on the spectrum 
is Prussian blue, and is usually incorporated in to my skies, water 
scenes, and shadowing.

Short Bio: My
early works began in the late 80’s, mainly sketches using coal and colored
pencils.  In 1996 I began working with
oils and acrylics in a folk art style with subjects including animal
miniatures, farms, flowers, trees, and field animals.  I completed several
full-length wall murals during this time. In 2010, my husband and I moved to
Cape Coral Florida from Washington State.  I was inspired to change my
artistic styling from folk art to abstract works with focus on ample, bold
colors.  The beautiful sunrise, sunsets, and of course, the cute burrowing
owls, native to our area, opened the door rekindle my passion for painting and
expand my art skills.  Additional inspiration comes from years of
traveling as a military brat and spouse.  I have been blessed to see the
beautiful landscapes and wildlife from growing-up in Guam, Louisiana, Germany,
New Mexico, and Washington.  

My focus these past 5-years has been abstract color techniques including
blending, staining, resin pours, and subtraction processes.  All artwork is on gallery
wrapped canvas, ranging from 10” X 10” up to 60” x 60”. 
I have my degree in Business Administration, am
a Florida State Certified Business Consultant, and a Certified Marketing
Strategist through Cornell University. My
husband and I have two grown sons and are looking forward to grandchildren and our
exciting new life in Florida. I also am
an avid paddle boarder, acoustic guitarist and pianist, and enjoy cooking. Mastering the
art of color and nature is my first passion and I am elated to share my artwork
with you.
Other Ways You Can Help If you can't contribute, here is how you can help:  Please get the word out and make some noise about the campaign.
Share with your friends via email and social media
 Use the Indiegogo share tools and blast on social media!   And..that's about it - Thank you all for supporting the arts!

story:
Short Summary

8 Little Zombies just received its foreward from Svengoolie! (Thanks, Sven!).

We're planning a publisher version but that won't be out until Fall of 2016 so we're doing a limited edition hardcover first printing here, in the USA (actually in Michigan) - just in time for the Halloween / Holiday Gift season!

This 32 page hardcover book, printed on high quality Sappi art paper, will be a one time printing - some elements may change when it goes to the publisher so it will be a true collector's version and simply - a boon to those who have been patiently waiting to hold and read the whole book!

What We Need & What You Get

We're looking to raise some of the printing costs through this campaign - it will get printed one way or another but we'd really like your help in getting it in hands of the fans like yourself. 

We've laid out less expensive options than our previous "all or nothing" campaigns, kept it simple because we want to reward the patience and support of our audience.

The Impact

Your pre-purchase will be making all the difference in sending us to press! The sooner we raise this Indiegogo fund of $3,000, the sooner we go to press - it may arrive early!

Risks & Challenges

We've been selling our plush to raise the balance of the print run and are supporting this campaign personally - if you support us here, you will be reading 8 Little Zombies in November! (if not before...).

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't support us with the purchase of a book, please consider sharing our campaign on Facebook, Twitter or your favorite social media.

If you're a fan who has been waiting and has already bought a zombie plush, please share some pics with us!

story:
Many people don't like reading a lot of text, so the 2-panel comics and art in the Vegan Artbook are the perfect solution to spread the vegan message in a creative and thought-provoking way.

The Vegan Artbook MILD contains 320 pages of colourful artwork and comics, focused on veganism, ethics, the environment, food, peace, love and animals. Aside from spreading cuteness, the book also raises awareness and shows people how they can make healthier and more ethical choices in their daily lives... all via artwork and mini-comics.

These unique books are therefore the perfect gift for vegans and vegetarians or people who are interested in this ethical life philosophy. Because of the colourful cartoonish art style, the books especially aim at people who are visually oriented and young people such as teenagers (who often don’t like to read a lot of text) and it teaches our future generations how to make the world a better place. This book is free of gory images, so it's suitable for people of all ages.

I've been working on these books for many months but because I am still studying, I lack the funds to publish the Vegan Artbook MILD. The Vegan Artbook MILD is planned for an september release and I need your help to make it happen. If you think my project is valuable, please help me realize it by helping me fund the publication of this book. Everything will be produced environmentally friendly, but also in very high quality on smooth recycled paper! Printing a full-colour book like this with 320 pages in small quantities is quite expensive here, so I'll be very grateful for every bit of help I can get on this.

This is one of the unique VAB mugs you will receive if you claim reward 8, 9 or 10. There is also a different design availible.

Your money will be used for the printing and publication of the artbook. All other costs (like copic markers & other drawing materials) will be paid with the money from my own pocket. Vegan Artbook has been a non-profit project until now. The previous book (SPICY) was a free book and people only paid for printing and shipping costs. I think that, for a project like this, money isn't important. The most important thing is spreading compassion and literally save lives that way.

Don't forget to check the video for more information!
And please share a link to this crowdfunding page!
Thank you everyone! I love you all!
