story:
BERLIN - REFLECTION - REFLEXION DER STADT

Discover your awareness

How adorable is this?!

What's the project about?
Art frees your mind. To feed our souls, we need purposeless and non-commercial images. But where are those in daily life?

As an artist, I am interested in the impact of images. My idea is to show art in the city of Berlin exactly at those places where we are used to see advertisements of the newest fashion and mobile phones. The images I create are exactly the opposite of an advertisement as they have pure black-and-white asthetics. They reflect the surrounding area: parked cars or shining facades. These unusual asthetics catches your attention!

What are our aims and who is our target audience?


George Bolik, the organizer of 'Kunstdetektor – studio tours in Berlin Charlottenburg', invited me to realise my project idea in November 2015. 30 studios of professional artists open their doors and there will be tours provided. While wandering around the area of Charlottenburg, you pass by the billboards for which I created my artworks. You can get a first hand experience of art in studios and on the streets – what a great combination!

Because billboards are very expensive, we need your support! We have to pay for the print and the location itself to realize the project.

With the project we want to reach people in Berlin and invite them to an exciting tour through Berlin Charlottenburg and the neighbouring area of Schöneberg. We would be very happy, if people from around Berlin come and find their way to the city on the weekend of 8th and 9th November to be part of an exceptional art event. But nevertheless it's our great wish to share the idea of the project with people all over the world. Art can be visible for everybody in the city.

Why should you support this project?
If you support the project 'Reflection - Reflexion der Stadt', you contribute to the realisation of a unique idea! Art opens your eyes and reminds you of your own presence in the dullness of everyday life. This happens, when you see unexpected black and white images instead of repeating advertisements.

How will the money be spent if the fundraising is sucessful?


You can see more than 18 billboards at interesting locations in Berlin Charlottenburg from 3rd to 12th November and celebrate with us at the opening party on 5th November! The donations go directly into the realisation of the project, no matter if the complete sum will be achieved or not. In case there are not enough funds, we try to find sponsors or minimize project spending – which we don't like to do.

Who is behind the project?

The creative mind behind 'Reflection – Reflexion der Stadt' is Angela Stauber. She studied at the Art Academy, Munich, with Jerry Zeniuk and Sean Scully and graduated as a master student in 2005. Since then she works internationally as an artist, living in London right now.

George Bolik is the CEO of 'art detector'. Since 20 years he works as a freelance curator, strategy consultant and coach.

story:
In Arabic is sweet! Let’s show the world the beauty of Arabic letters!

Hi! I am Mohamed Shoukry. Through my whole life, I am fond of Arabic letters and calligraphy. That is why I love to show the world how beautiful Arabic letters are. 

Sample Arabic Calligraphy designs.


About 7 years ago, I already started a self-funding project to create T-Shirts with Arabian designs. We already made the first pilot designs, printed them on T-Shirts and started to distribute them. We had some success and we showed up in some media TV programs. You can check the gallery for an interview with TV program.

Have a look at the designs we made that time:

 design 01: In Arabic is sweet

design 02: In Arabic is sweet

design 03: Youth is the Future

As I became responsible for a family, I had to abandon my life dream project temporary to focus on my career as a software developer. 

Now, I made my mind to come back and continue what I begun 7 years ago. We will make a new production line with Arabic Calligraphy designed T-Shirts that show the world how beautiful Arabic letters are. 

We will have a professional digital TShirts printer. We have chosen TShirts material from pure Egyptian cotton. Our design team is composed of professional Arabic Calligraphy designers. So, we are ready for it, do you??

Now, we give you the chance to get on board with us!! We will buy a professional TShirts digital printer and will market for our new production line to reach maximum number of audience.

Did you check our new designs ready for printing? You will have yours once you select you perk,   Have a look:

design 04: Arabic Alphabet

design 05: A Tiger with Arabic letters.

design 06: Arabic Letters Tree

design 07: Pen is Knowledge

design 08: Knowledge is Light.

design 09: Arabic "No" word.

design 10: Random Arabic Letters.



What Can You Do To get on board?

  • You can be part of our dream and make it real by pledging to our crowdfunding campaign and open this Art gate to the world.

  • We all need to do our best to raise the role of Art in our world to become a cross messenger between people in the whole world.  By contributing to ‘In Arabic is sweet’ you will be one step closer .

Other Ways You Can Help

  • We understand that some people just can't contribute, but this doesn't mean you can't help.

  • You can help by emailing your friends this campaign and to share it on Facebook, Twitter.


Here are our social media links:
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/pages/In-Arabic-is-swe...
Twitter: @mohamedShoukry 

Thank you for all your support so far and helping us earn our wings.

and In Arabic is sweet :)

story:
Hello and welcome to Moments of Joy

This is art that tells a story—about living with Alzheimer’s.  It’s never easy but there are moments of joy—sometimes a lot, sometimes not so much—but joy nonetheless.

In the first exhibition of its kind in Seattle, this surprising, delightful and inspiring art will allow us to experience these moments—opening hearts and minds to remarkable people.  At Moments of Joy, intriguing art creates a different way of thinking about dementia, enabling us to see that—though they have changed—they are still here, living with dignity, creativity and joy.

This turns everything I thought I knew about Alzheimer’s on its head.  I thought of these people—if I thought of them at all—as gone, as no longer of value and these paintings just changed that completely.  And what is so wonderful about the exhibition is that we can meet them as artists—as people—as people we care about.   Liz H.


About the Exhibition

Free and open to all, the exhibition will feature fascinating paintings by nearly 40 people, aged 60 to 96, who live with dementia.  Opening at Seattle City Hall’s Lobby Gallery & Anne Focke Gallery on January 8, 2016 and on view to the public through February 26, 2016 in partnership with Seattle’s Office of Arts and Culture.  And there’s more…

Throughout the seven weeks of the exhibition, we will present a series of activities developed in concert with exhibit partners – catalysts for knowledge, empathy, creativity and involvement.

·  Gallery walks, panel discussions, guest speakers and performances reflecting diverse perspectives—artists, caregivers, students, neurologists, social workers, policy makers and people living with dementia.

·  A series of free outreach painting classes expanding access to these valuable arts programs.

·  A Word Cloud showing us the impact of the art in real time as attendees answer the question, “What word describes this exhibition?”


The inspiration

In Loving Memory of Jean McFee Raichle – March 28, 1919 – April 19, 2015

I was raised in the shadow of Alzheimer’s with nearly everyone on my father’s side and many in mother’s developing the disease.  We were taught that when Alzheimer’s arrived, it was like a death—actually worse than death.  Our parents warned us, “Don’t sacrifice your lives for us.  When our time comes, just walk away.” And I believed it. 

And then Mom began to paint.  The paintings were amazing.  She had never painted a day in her life yet these paintings were really good, always interesting and sometimes remarkable.  And slowly, I began to understand.  She may have had a short term memory of about ten seconds, but she was still here—loving, creative and joyful.  I began to share the art with others and the reaction was always the same—delight, surprise and gratitude to experience a story about Alzheimer’s with hope and joy—a continual discovery of what it means to be human.

Fascinating. If you believe art is a medium for communication, it appears this woman has more than a few things to say to us.  Kitty S.

The impact

While Alzheimer’s is scary, art isn’t.  It is our hope that the exhibition will encourage a leap from fear to connection, creative thinking and involvement.  Leading to real conversations about how to build a dementia friendly community—more inclusive, more engaging, more supportive and more hopeful for everyone whose lives are touched by dementia.  And if we are really lucky, we will become better stewards of an aging population—which, after all, ultimately means all of us.


What will your money do?

Your contribution will help us fund the final $4,625 needed to launch the initial exhibition.

The entire project has a budget of $28,975. Thanks to some wonderful sponsors and a few visionary individuals, we have raised $19,350 with a pledge of $5,000 waiting in the wings.  This leaves us with $4,625 left to raise to fully fund the project. 

·  The biggest chunk goes to the framing of the art.  All of the paintings are on loan from the artists and their families with our promise that we will return them in good condition and professionally framed. 

·  Then comes the design and printing of exhibit materials: the postcards and catalog of all the  exhibited works as well as wall titles/tags/display boards

·  Marketing and outreach to spread the word

·  Next, the screen and projector for the Word Cloud

·  And finally, eight free outreach art classes  


What do you get for backing us? Perks!

Of course, you can back us just because you see the value in this project and for this we will shower you with appreciation on social media and the website.  Select a perk (or a few) and we will send you postcards of the art, the catalog—digital or printed—prints of the art and reserved seating to special events.  There are even a few opportunities to select an original painting by my mother Jean.  Check out the perks for more details.

Thanks to the Kenneth and Marleen Alhadeff Charitable Foundation, the first $500 will be matched 1:1.

And because we are Powered by Shunpike, your gift is tax-deductible!

So why should you back this project?

Because really—you can never have too many moments of joy in this life.

Risks & Challenges
If we don't raise our total goal, we will adjust at the edges—fewer printed materials, more work for more volunteers—but the core remains: extraordinary art by remarkable people on view to the public.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to make a donation, but would still like to support us, you can do so by SHARING this campaign with EVERYONE YOU KNOW! Email, phone calls, Twitter, Instagram, Facebook, text messages, hand written letters.  We are grateful for all the support you can give us.  

Thank you!


The Artists represented above are: Sue Gardon, Jane Kippenhan, Jean McFee Raichle, H. David Jones and Mike Todd
Our Sponsors: Seattle Department of Neighborhoods, 4Culture and the Kenneth and Marleen Alhadeff Charitable Foundation .  Media Sponsor - KUOW
Community Partners: 

Alzheimer’s Association Washington State Chapter, Elderwise, Frye Art Museum Creative Aging Program, Full Life, Greenwood Senior Center, Horizon House, Northwest Center for Creative Aging, Seattle Senior Services, Skyline Seattle, The Hearthstone, UW Medicine, Memory and Brain Wellness Center, UW School of Nursing, de Tornyay Center for Healthy Aging, UW School of Social WorkIn-kind Special thanks to:  Joel Heflin / Mainframe Shop LLC, John Engerman / Bicameral Design and everyone at Girlie Press.
story_txt:
Hello and welcome to Moments of Joy
This is art that tells a story—about living with Alzheimer’s.  It’s
never easy but there are moments of joy—sometimes a lot, sometimes not so
much—but joy nonetheless. 
In
the first exhibition of its kind in Seattle, this surprising, delightful and
inspiring art will allow us to experience these moments—opening hearts and
minds to remarkable people.  At Moments
of Joy, intriguing art creates a different way of thinking about dementia,
enabling us to see that—though they have changed—they are still here,
living with dignity, creativity and joy.


This turns everything I thought I knew about
Alzheimer’s on its head.  I thought of these people—if I thought of them at all—as gone, as no longer of
value and these paintings just changed that completely.  And what is so
wonderful about the exhibition is that we can meet them as artists—as people—as people we care about.   Liz H.
About the Exhibition
Free and open to all, the exhibition will feature fascinating paintings
by nearly 40 people, aged 60 to 96, who live with dementia.  Opening at Seattle City Hall’s Lobby Gallery & Anne Focke Gallery on January 8,
2016 and on view to the public through February 26, 2016 in partnership with
Seattle’s Office of Arts and Culture.  And there’s more…
Throughout
the seven weeks of the exhibition, we will present a series of activities developed
in concert with exhibit partners – catalysts for knowledge, empathy,
creativity and involvement.
· 
Gallery
walks, panel discussions, guest speakers and performances reflecting diverse perspectives—artists,
caregivers, students, neurologists, social workers, policy makers and people
living with dementia. 
· 
A series
of free outreach painting classes expanding access to these valuable arts
programs. 
· 
A Word
Cloud showing us the impact of the art in real time as attendees answer the question,
“What word describes this exhibition?” 




The inspiration

In Loving Memory of Jean McFee Raichle – March 28, 1919 – April 19, 2015
I was raised in the shadow of Alzheimer’s with nearly
everyone on my father’s side and many in mother’s developing the disease. 
We were taught that when Alzheimer’s arrived, it was like a death—actually
worse than death.  Our parents warned us, “Don’t sacrifice your lives for
us.  When our time comes, just walk away.” And I believed
it.  
And then Mom began to paint.  The paintings were amazing.  She had
never painted a day in her life yet these paintings were really good, always
interesting and sometimes remarkable.  And slowly, I began to
understand.  She may have had a short term memory of about ten seconds,
but she was still here—loving, creative and joyful.  I began to
share the art with others and the reaction was always the same—delight,
surprise and gratitude to experience a story about Alzheimer’s with hope and
joy—a continual discovery of what it means to be human.



Fascinating. If you believe art is a medium for
communication, it appears this woman has more than a few things to say to us.  Kitty S.
The impact
While Alzheimer’s is scary, art isn’t.  It is our hope that the exhibition will encourage
a leap from fear to connection, creative thinking and involvement.  Leading to real conversations about how to
build a dementia friendly community—more inclusive, more engaging, more
supportive and more hopeful for everyone whose lives are touched by dementia.  And if we are really lucky, we will become better stewards of an aging population—which, after all, ultimately means
all of us.




What
will your money do?

Your contribution will help us fund
the final $4,625 needed to launch the initial exhibition.
The entire project has a budget of
$28,975. Thanks to some wonderful sponsors and a few visionary
individuals, we have raised $19,350 with a pledge of $5,000 waiting in the
wings.  This leaves us with $4,625 left to
raise to fully fund the project.  
·  The biggest chunk goes to the framing of the art.  All of the
paintings are on loan from the artists and their families with our promise that
we will return them in good condition and professionally framed.  
·  Then comes the design and printing of exhibit materials: the
postcards and catalog of all the 
exhibited works as well as wall titles/tags/display boards 
·  Marketing and outreach to spread the word
·  Next, the screen and projector for the Word Cloud 
·  And finally, eight free outreach art classes   





What
do you get for backing us? Perks!

Of course, you can back us just
because you see the value in this project and for this we will shower you with appreciation
on social media and the website.  Select
a perk (or a few) and we will send you postcards of the art, the catalog—digital
or printed—prints of the art and reserved seating to special events.  There are even a few opportunities to select an
original painting by my mother Jean.  Check
out the perks for more details.
Thanks to the Kenneth and Marleen Alhadeff Charitable Foundation, the first $500 will be matched 1:1.
And because we are Powered by Shunpike, your gift is tax-deductible!
So
why should you back this project?
Because really—you can never have
too many moments of joy in this life.
Risks & ChallengesIf we don't raise our total goal, we will adjust at the edges—fewer printed materials, more work for more volunteers—but the core remains: extraordinary art by remarkable people on view to the public.Other Ways You Can Help
 If you are unable to make a donation, but would still like to support 
us, you can do so by SHARING this campaign with EVERYONE YOU KNOW! 
Email, phone calls, Twitter, Instagram, Facebook, text messages, 
hand written letters.  We are grateful for all the 
support you can give us.  


Thank you!
The Artists represented above are: Sue Gardon, Jane Kippenhan, Jean McFee Raichle, H. David Jones and Mike ToddOur Sponsors: Seattle Department of Neighborhoods, 4Culture and the Kenneth and Marleen Alhadeff Charitable Foundation .  Media Sponsor - KUOWCommunity Partners:  Alzheimer’s Association Washington State Chapter,
Elderwise, Frye Art Museum Creative Aging Program, Full Life, Greenwood Senior
Center, Horizon House, Northwest Center for Creative Aging, Seattle Senior
Services, Skyline Seattle, The Hearthstone, UW Medicine, Memory and Brain
Wellness Center, UW School of Nursing, de Tornyay Center for Healthy Aging, UW
School of Social WorkIn-kind Special thanks to:  Joel Heflin / Mainframe Shop LLC, John Engerman / Bicameral Design and everyone at Girlie Press.

story:
Short Summary about e-l@ugh

e-l@ugh from Amsterdam, triggers a giggle from China, a roar from Rio, an outburst in Lagos, guffows in Teheran, jesting in Johannesburg or a bursting e-l@ugh in San Francisco.
WHO AM I ?  My name is Godelieve Smulders from Amsterdam, pleased to meet you here !  I am a multi-disciplined artist working in sculpture, painting, drawing and new social media.

WHY AS AN ARTIST AM I PRESENTING ..... e-l@ugh ..... TO THE WORLD?   As the world is so politically, culturally and religiously divided at the moment ..... my passionate wish is  to find a common ground for all of us;.  Laughter is as universal as music, personal as a fingerprint, an instinct which a person from any culture significantly recognises.The shortest road to one an other, a fantastic beautiful human phenomenon to be honored in this largest and lightest artwork ever!

THE IDEA   By  massively sending zigzagging internet laughs all over the globe we envision digitally WRAPPING THE WORLD IN LAUGHTER. So the essence of the project  is connection, the format is l@ughter, the final products are a compilation movie of the most authentic laughs offered to the UN as a sign of connection and a book with all 199 countries represented; laughing.

HOW TO PROCEED We  have created smart phone APPs for Android and Apple mobile phones.You can download the APPs for free! L@ugh with friends or family and record your own video with the app.  Upload the video!  You can share your video through social media.  Or alternatively, see yourself  connected with other world l@ughers !

RIGHT TO PLAY                                                                                                                                    By uploading your l@ugh you will support Right To Play, a non-profit organization who teaches and empowers children through sport- & play based activities in more than 20 countries worldwide. Every upload of your l@ughter will pay for helping kids laugh again !.

PREVIOUS WORK   We succesfully created a global audio project about laughter, to welcome the new Millennium in on 1st January, 2000, named the World Laughter Monument.   More information on www.laughterlab.com and e-l@ugh.com concerning our various projects.                       

WHY WOULD WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT?  Help us reach 37.000 dollar with which we can  improve the  APPs which are available already in Apple's App Store and in Google's Play Store but really needs to be improved. We need money to make sure the project goes worldwide, run a site, a server, publish a book and create a movie downloadable for everyone,  We need many hands to realize this. You will enjoy and l@ugh a lot with the perks I am offering here. :)

CALL FOR ACTION   Please help us in making this e-l@ugh video project work! Thereby displaying our wonderful basic primal human connection through universal l@ughter.  With your support we can make a difference, connect and lighten up the world. Get the word out and the l@ugh wrapped around. Laugh is in the air and ready to take the world on. Use the Indiegogo share tools

Thank you for all your care and support !  It means a lot to me and my team.

Sincerely, Godelieve and team

Keep e-l@ugh   ........ ing.

story:
Place x Place

When I went to Dhaka, Bangladesh in 2010 the shock to my system was nearly overwhelming. Dhaka City is the size of my small home county of Fayette, in Kentucky, but holds nearly 4 times the number of people in my entire state! Everything was different, it seemed. Until I realized it wasn't. In fact, despite the glaring difference, it reminded of my Appalachian home, particularly. Huh? Because, people are absolutely more alike than different. Like Bangladeshis, we in Appalachia we know a thing or two about fishing, about beautiful land and the cost of its use, and about making due. But, conventional power media emphasizes difference. Muslim vs. Christian, Brown vs. White, Them vs. Us. I came home eager to "do something". But what could be done? 

It took five years and another visit to come to realize a vision. My wish was to enable real and deep connection in a way that bypassed conventional media. I met a writer, Robert Gipe, teaching in Harlan, Kentucky. I made my pitch—"Your students are told every day that Muslims are the enemy. That the other side of the world is alien, and that we are free to exploit them. I know better. Students in Dhaka are just like students in Kentucky.

I created the website Harlan X Dhaka (pronounced Harlan "by" Dhaka). I designed this simple format: Both participants upload their pictures as "seeds". Then, the students choose to match their photos into pairs called Threads . These threads become the art of the effort: a series of pieces celebrating the commonality.

Place X Place is a teaching tool based on Harlan x Dhaka. The premise is simple: starting with the presumption of mutual ignorance, and of distance, two groups of people will use contemporary technology and playfully create "rhyming images". The results are artistic, educational, resonant. Please see Harlan X Dhaka for example.

With your help our team will build a web-based tool based on the architecture of Harlan X Dhaka that will enable any two groups of people to pair up and have a similar exchange.

Our vision includes:

A stand alone web tool.

Portability across all platforms.

Easy-to-use functionality.

Scalability and ease-of-management.

Ability to 'sign on' with a paired city in mind, or, to sign up as a 'single' (for example: 7th grade classroom in Santa Fe, New Mexico seeks similar outside North America).

Option to order end of project product to commemorate experience, such as classroom poster or book.


What We Need & What You Get

  • We need money to universalize the format as Place x Place, and to advertise and publish the tool using web designers.
  • At $20 or more, you will be named as a contributor on the website and receive a magnet bearing one of the original paired images. At $50 or more, you'll receive the magnet, a t-shirt bearing an original image and credit. At $500, you'll receive recognition as a Founder, plus all other gifts.
  • We will hire web developers and technical writers to create an air-tight, scalable format for Place x Place; we will buy more time to keep Harlan x Dhaka up; we will fulfill, insofar as possible, our original goal to share the ability to follow this format via a general website.

The Impact

Your contribution will provide a "plug and play" tool that will enable teachers, leaders, or any other motivators to learn and share globally, with a beautiful end result at very little cost:

  • Without participation, we turn judgmental and arrogant. With investment, we become interested and compassionate.
  • I have experience making art on a shoestring. With the help of a few friends, I created and directed the film Elbow of Light for less than $20,000.00.
  • Place x Place isn't about a product, but about the process of seeing, sharing, and creating by the participants. Harlan x Dhaka is evidence that it works.

Risks & Challenges

Reaching across cultural, political and religious lines can be scary. This project needs to be simple, above all.

With a good format, and simple architecture, we can enable leaders to overcome these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Most of our expenses are for skilled web-builders. You can volunteer to help!

story:
Free Range Art...Three Years Later

What began as a simple experiment designed to make the entire Fusebox Festival free to attend has produced some dramatic outcomes. Here’s what we’ve discovered so far:

  • 60% increase in first-time festival goers in both 2014 and 2015

  • On average, people attended twice as many events--demonstrating a much deeper level of engagement

  • Our “Respect the Reservation” campaign has had a 97% success rate

The initiative has also allowed us to spark numerous conversations locally, nationally, and internationally about access (i.e. who has access to this work and who is it for), as well as a bigger dialogue about the economics of making art & performance.


Ultimately, the campaign was designed to take the most basic mechanism of the festival, the simple act of buying a ticket, and turn it into a bigger conversation that asks, “How can we make this vital, important work more accessible to everyone, AND how do we as a community want to pay for it? And if we zoom out a bit, can we imagine a different sort of relationship between art, artist, and audience that is less transactional and more about engagement, discovery, and ongoing exploration?”


Fusebox > Festival

By supporting Fusebox you are doing more than simply supporting Free Range Art. As an organization our work is a year-round endeavor. Each festival is years in the making. And as our organization has grown, so has our connection with our own community. We love the idea that an arts organization can present cutting-edge artists from around the region/world AND be meaningfully engaged with our community in real ways. To this end, we are actively engaging with our community to explore the most vital issues facing our city (affordability, gentrification, community health, education, etc) in an attempt to shake up the status quo and create meaningful, out-of-the-box solutions.

Your support through this campaign makes all of this possible and allows us to better plan all of our activities and programs.



Experiments are Breadth Fresheners

In many ways, the past twelve years of Fusebox have been an ongoing experiment investigating the idea of “festival”. What makes a festival a festival? What are things that only a festival can do? For our 2016 festival, we wanted to experiment with density to create an immersive festival environment. This experiment is designed to explore two things we absolutely love about festivals: 1) We think festivals (at their best) are great at creating vibrant, temporary communities. 2) We also love that festivals (at their best) create a space for the unpredictable collision of ideas and perspectives. Encountering multiple artists with diverse perspectives becomes an act of discovery.

Here’s what to expect for the 2016 Fusebox Festival:

  • The festival will run for five days, April 6-10

  • Local/National/International: Artists from four continents + Canada & Mexico -- All 100% free to attend

  • More programming throughout the day, all day

  • More talks, workshops, and opportunities to connect with the work

  • Our new central Festival hub at the Saengerrunde Hall. Think performances+music+drinks+bowling+fun...

What does my donation actually do?

Quite simply, your donation brings the 2016 Fusebox Festival to life. That’s hundreds of extraordinary artists, performances, talks, panels, workshops, and parties--free to attend for you and all your friends. But your help is essential. Consider this:

  • We have 3 weeks to raise at least $25,000

  • 100% of the funds from this campaign will go to support artists featured in the 2016 Fusebox Festival

  • Your donation gets you some amazing perks: a one-of-a-kind arts festival, advance reservations, highly-coveted swag, and a new Adventureship program.

Respect the Reservation!

Just like the last two years, you will be able to make advance reservations in our free festival model with our Respect the Reservation campaign. This is super important to us. You can read more about it HERE. In short, we want you to be able to plan your festival experience and have the best time possible, but we also ask that you don't over-book and flake out on shows that you have reservations for as there are other people in the community that would also like to attend. Over the past two years, 97% of attendees respected the reservation. Way to go everyone!


It's not ALL about the Benjamins

There are lots of ways you can help without actually making a cash donation. Here are a few simple ways you can really help Fusebox and this campaign:

  • Volunteer for the festival (you can find more information HERE).

  • Help to spread the word about this campaign by sharing links and messages with your friends and family.

  • Attend the Fusebox Festival - we genuinely need financial support, but the most important outcome for a free festival is that everyone feels welcome to engage as much as they like without cost getting in the way.

Attend the Fusebox Festival - we genuinely need financial support, but the most important outcome for a free festival is that everyone feels welcome to engage as much as they like without cost getting in the way.

story:
Our story

Hello I'm Gina Hartmann founder of NOW open studio. NOW was started in 2010 first in CA before moving to Portland, OR. When NOW opened it's doors the primary focus was coaching creative thinking. The courses were designed to stimulate creative process, open the mind, think differently, and push creativity.
One of the most common problems artist, musicians, writers and all creatives suffer from is mental block or commonly heard writers block. A stall or complete shut down of the creative process. Less destructive but just as common to be stuck in a rut of repetitive behavior. 
After having a successful career in Advertising / Marketing for over a decade, I left the field to return to fine art. I wanted to make use of the skills acquired and time spent in the commercial field. The courses I developed to redirect and stimulate creative thought are based on rapid thought and idea generation techniques used in the Ad world. Where time does not stand still for creative blocks and where deadlines must be met.
In 2014 NOW refocused it's vision. NOW needed to become a vehicle to allow artist to become truly enveloped in creative stimulation. Hence our decision to reinvent ourselves. NOW is putting a twist on the idea of the artist retreat. Unlike other retreats our goal is to work on the health of creativity not work on technique or skill building. The biggest problem with the standard retreat model is cost. Artists register and if excepted generally can not afford the expense of staying, which can cost $1200. a week and upwards. Most artists maybe able to cover their cost to get there, but the stay is out of reach. Keeping many talented creatives from applying. 
NOW is different, if excepted into the program the artist receives a two week coaching session and will be welcomed as our guest to stay at the Garden Room. The Garden Room is private with a full bath. French doors open up into a lush garden were an outdoor painting /drawing area will also be available. With only the responsibility of transportation to get there on the artist, it will better allow the them the ability to take advantage of Portland's incredible art, outdoor, food, and music scene. Plus allow for greater concentration on the program of creative stimulation.
NOW is located in Sellwood a beautiful old grid system neighborhood four miles from downtown Portland. Steps away from public trains, buses and bike paths. Artists are able to explore Portland, a vibrant creative city.
Artist registration fee is $25.00 much lower then most registration fees. Judging will be based on technique, skill, craft, and vision first. The artist CV/resume will be taken into account second. The NOW team and invited judges from the vast Portland creative community will vote on who is excepted into the program. The creative stimulation sessions offered will start with visual arts first then later add sessions for writers, musicians and other creative fields. 
The NOW team provides a much needed survice for creatives and the creative minded. Art is vastly important to the world. It is the common thread allowing us to all share in the human experience and connect on a higher level. Your donations will allow us to expand the garden and outdoor painting/drawing space, provide up to date art media and publications and up date the Garden Room into a relaxing oasis.

Thank you for taking the time to learn about us. Please check out our wonderful perks. 
Visit our website to learn more NOWOPENSTUDIO.com

story:
I want to thank everyone for their support for the successful trip to Mount Everest
and the setting the World Record for Making a Pot AT THE HIGHEST ALTITUDE EVER.
I received the most incredible emails and Facebook posts from friends and family. 
Making a Pot on Everest Part II funding campaign will allow us to expand scholarships to other schools in Sonoma County by offering the limited edition pieces made on Mt. Everest to contributors so we can continue raising money for our Scholarship Fund.  The Scholarship Fund assists graduating high school seniors to pursue their passion in the arts. All art forms are included: music, drama, painting, sculpture, design, ceramics, culinary, photography and anything else that is considered "the Arts".

Background: Robert graduated from Otis Art Institute where he received his Master's degree in Fine Arts. He has been making high fire ceramics for over 50 years. 
He and his wife, Patricia, created a scholarship fund 13 years ago to encourage art students to go on to college.  The fund has awarded 63 scholarships to date.  All the profit from the sales of Robert's porcelain and photography is awarded to graduating high school art students.

Purpose: Making a Pot on Mount Everest Part II campaign, will continue to promote awareness of our fund, help us to expand to more Sonoma County High Schools and give these young artists the recognition they deserve. Robert strongly feels that  acknowledging these emerging artists is a way to give encouragement so that they will pursue their passion in art. 

Goal: This funding campaign will allow us to expand scholarships to other schools in Sonoma County.  All funds raised here will go directly to graduating high school students. 
  • We are looking to raise $2,500 all of which will go to graduating art students. 
  • Your contribution will help us reach our goal. Every Everest piece is a molded piece of the original hand thrown on Mount Everest, signed and numbered by Robert. 
  • Here is what we offer:

For a $100 donation
1 limited edition piece made at high altitude on Mt. Everest

Three of the first finished pieces. They are about 5 1/2" tall and 4" wide. 
The piece is named the Himalaya bottle as the rings at the top
represent the four tallest mountains in the world. Robert has a photo he will soon share of these mountains shot from Mount Everest.

For a donation of $100 you will receive a hand cast piece of the world record item that Robert threw on Everest. On the bottom of each piece is written Mt. Everest, signed by Robert with his insignia. Numbering is based on the time 
your contribution is received. 
The pieces are glazed with several crystalline glazes Robert has developed over the past several years. The first contributors to the campaign receive the lowest numbered of the 200 pieces.
This is a limited edition of 200 pieces. After the 200 are sold, the mold will be destroyed.  Below are other perks you can receive.

For a $35 donation, you will receive a SMALL hand-thrown tumbler finished with Robert's special crystalline glaze.  All pieces will be numbered and signed.

For a $55 donation, you will receive a larger hand-thrown tumbler finished with Robert's special crystalline glaze.  All pieces will be numbered and signed.

For a $75 donation, you will receive two larger hand-thrown tumblers finished with Robert's special crystalline glaze.  All pieces will be numbered and signed.

For a $500 donation, you will receive:

  • One set of 4 crystalline-glazed mugs
  • One limited edition piece (see the $100 item)
  • A One-Hour Demonstration for You and Your Friends at Robert's studio in Healdsburg

For ALL Contributions:

  • You have a choice to come to Robert's studio to meet him and pick up your pieces or they will be shipped at no cost.
  • Whether the goal is reached or not, all funds go to graduating art students to assist them in pursuing their future in the arts. 
*Please note:

  • A tumbler is without a handle, as opposed to mugs that have a handle.
  • Colors, shapes, and sizes vary.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Karen and I am a wife and mother, a pupil support assistant in a local primary school and a textile artist.

I began my creative journey many years ago in Nairn Academy where I was inspired and encouraged by a fantastic art teacher.  I then moved on to Inverness College to prepare my portfolio with the intention of moving on to university to study the subject in depth. Here I met my future husband and my wonderful life took over. 

 It was some 20 years later when my children were becoming more independent that I picked up my art tools again and my passion was reignited.

I create my art using different textiles and fibres, one of the main techniques I use is called needle felting.

Needle felting is bonding fibres together using a sharp barbed needle that is repeatedly stabbed through the fibres.  These fibres are layered like paint to give each piece a depth and vibrancy that brings them to life.

Art has given me confidence in myself and my abilities both as an artist and as an educator.  I have been teaching others the technique of needle felting for the past two years in various locations within the local area.  People of all ages and abilities have attended these classes where I take them through the techniques needed to transform my vast range of fibres  into their own unique piece of art.  These workshops have led to people taking up needle felting as a hobby and some have even made a business out of it,  I am proud to have been part part of their creative journeys.

'Following my passion is one way I show love to myself........Sharing it is my way of inspiring self love to all who cross my path.....'  (quote by unknown author)

I want to build a small studio/ gallery at the edge of my garden where I can create, teach and sell art.

I live near to Lochness, next to a  road that is very busy during the summer months with tourists cycling, walking and driving by constantly.  Initially the  gallery will be open at weekends and throughout the school  holidays the opening hours will be extended.  

The gallery will be multi functional, with room for intimate workshops to be held where students will have easy access to my materials and be working in an inspiring environment surrounded by art and with views of the countryside from all angles.  

It will also be a space for myself to display and sell my art and  printed goods including mugs and greetings cards that I have had made showing my images.

 Local artists and craft people will be invited to have their goods for sale.  The nearest gallery is over 20 miles away so this would provide a much needed platform to promote the range of high quality art and craftsmanship available in the area. 

If you are able to contribute in any way, you will be helping me to achieve my dream by giving people the opportunity to explore their creativity and to appreciate the joy of art.

What We Need & What You Get

I need your help to make my dream a reality. 
The money you donate will go towards the materials needed to build the gallery.  it will be approx 4 x 3 metres in size.  The external and internal wood, flooring, roofing, windows and  insulation,  Inside fittings and heating.  None of the money will be paid out on labour  which will help to keep the costs down. (Family members have offered their labour for free).
In return for your generosity you will be given a reward, these include signed prints, printed mugs and coasters, workshops and invitations to the gallery opening.
If I don't meet my goal of £2500 then all the money raised will be put into an account and I will continue to work to raise funds for the gallery.  If you have donated for one of the workshop perks and the goal is not met then I will honour the workshop but it will be held in an alternative location.

The Impact

This gallery will mean I can showcase my work to a new audience. 
 I can offer locals and visitors to the area workshops where they can explore their artistic side.  
There is a massive amount of undiscovered or unseen talent in this area and the gallery will be an opportunity for others to demonstrate their personal talents through exhibiting within.
 

Risks & Challenges

The challenges that I may come up against include not reaching my goal amount, I will overcome this as mentioned earlier by keeping any money donated in a separate account and I will carry on working hard to reach my goal by continuing to host workshops and attend craft fairs 
My work is starting to sell well and I always feel that face to face selling works best in the art world as people like to meet the artist and make a personal connection with them and their work.  Having a gallery in my garden will enable me to do just that while still being 'around' for my boys!
Once the gallery is built there will be no overheads such as rent as it will be built on my property, this means that the money can be spent on the best quality materials available for the build ensuring that the gallery lasts a lifetime and can inspire generations.


Other Ways You Can Help

I know that not everyone will be able to help but if you would take the time to share this on your facebook/twitter etc accounts I would really appreciate it x
Thank you so much for taking the time to read my campaign.  Please ask any questions if there is anything you are unsure of.

story:
Fini Dance Festival International Dance Award Italy- New York is a celebration of Italian International dancer and Choreographer. Held in Calabria, Italy and in New York  the festival celebrated art an culture including workshops and audition to create opportunity for young dancers and choreographer to travel between the to countries. 

My Name is Antonio Fini and I'm a native from Calabria south Italy, since 2007 I live in New York dancing from the Martha Graham Dance Ensemble, Michael Mao Dance to  Staten Island Ballet. 

Art and Culture is important to me as is important to celebrate the people that give their heart to it! Since 2011 I started the festival in Italy and in 2013 the one in New York celebrating masters of the dance world that are originally Italian like the father of dance LUIGI and the creator of the Miami City Ballet Edvard Villella. The gaol is to keep this bridge live! And for this year to bring the living legend Carla Fracci back to New York for her 80th birthday ! 

This found raiser will be a kick start. With $5000 we can start this venture. Please make your donation today before 2016 starts.

Tell your friends and family share our campaign. This is a little step and every donation counts. 

This is only the beginning more fundraising  to come!

story:
Short Summary

Hi there! If you don't know me, I'm an artist and jewelry maker in Minneapolis. I am going to Australia for the month of March to visit a dear friend and explore more of our world. I have decided to sell some of my work in order to fund my four weeks there!

What I Need & What You Get

I am trying to raise $1000 in order to secure food and lodging while I'm down under. With such a great current conversion rate, this will equal almost $1400 AUD! This will equal out to $50 a day.

Make a $20.00 contribution and you get a print of one of my favorite works.

For $35.00 you will receive a unique, one of a kind, gemstone necklace as well as the awesome print.

For $70.00, you receive a hand crafted gemstone body chain in addition to the crystal pendant necklace and print.

 Whoever gives the highest amount will receive an original 16"x20" illustration by me, inspired by my coming journey!

The Impact

With your help, I'll be able to take the most rewarding trip possible. Most of the money I've saved up will be put toward transportation around the east coast of the vast country (it's pretty much the size of the USA in terms of land). Imagine a month-long road trip from Florida to Maine! Your contributions will give me a place to rest my head along the coast.

You will also get a piece of art, and a custom piece of jewelry or two!

Risks & Challenges

Whatever I don't make in my funding goal, I'll have to put my transportation funding toward food and lodging. Ideally, I would love to have the opportunity to see as much of Australia as possible during this trip of a lifetime.

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell your friends! If anyone is looking to expand their art or accessories collection, this campaign is perfect for them!

Thank you so much!

story:
Hello!

We're Sache Primeaux-Shaw and Shana Prince, the founders of the newest bookstore and creative space in Oklahoma City--Black Lit. This bookstore will be based in Northeast OKC which is the predominantely Black area of town. It is a culturally rich area of town and we would love to honor that culture by having this space.  It can serve as a space for Open Mic poetry nights, panel discussions, book signings, book clubs and more. It will also be a safe space for children! 

Growing up, we did not have a bookstore in our community. Shana and I are both lovers of books and our families would have to drive across town in order to find bookstores. We also did not have very many safe spaces growing up. The library was the only place in the community that was a safe space. 

All we need is your support to make this idea a reality! So please support and spread the word. 


  • For this project, we will need approximately $20,000. We will need funding for the rental space, renovations (if needed) and licenses. 
  • These funds will also go towards the purchase of books and other items for the store. We are also looking towards having a space for a coffee shop with Wi-Fi so that will be added into the expenses. We will start small. 
  • If our goal is not reached, we will budget accordingly for our expenses most needed in creating the space and look for other avenues for funding.

This project is important because Northeast Oklahoma City has a rich culture in it's own right. There are several important landmarks that exist there including the OKC NAACP Youth Council center, Douglass High School, the first Black high school in Oklahoma, as well as the Ralph Ellison Library named for the famous author and product of the Harlem Renaissance. This bookstore can also serve as a safe space for the youth and college students that live in this area of town as well. 
With any new project, there will be risks and challenges. With ours, the main one will be maintaining funding and support. 


If you are unable to support financially, we would love for you to share our story with your friends through your social media venues!

All we need is your support to make this idea a reality! So please support and spread the word. 




For this project, we will need approximately $20,000. We will need funding for the rental space, renovations (if needed) and licenses. 


These funds will also go towards the purchase of books and other items for the store. We are also looking towards having a space for a coffee shop with Wi-Fi so that will be added into the expenses. We will start small. 


If our goal is not reached, we will budget accordingly for our expenses most needed in creating the space and look for other avenues for funding.


This project is important because Northeast Oklahoma City has a rich culture in it's own right. There are several important landmarks that exist there including the OKC NAACP Youth Council center, Douglass High School, the first Black high school in Oklahoma, as well as the Ralph Ellison Library named for the famous author and product of the Harlem Renaissance. This bookstore can also serve as a safe space for the youth and college students that live in this area of town as well. With any new project, there will be risks and challenges. With ours, the main one will be maintaining funding and support. 


If you are unable to support financially, we would love for you to share our story with your friends through your social media venues!

story:
Welcome to Mantra Hostel !

Mantra Hostel was concocted as inspiration drawn from Jacksonville Fl , Leon Mexico and New York artists.  Is the sum of chance encounters, rare opportunities, some tequila, some mezcal and very long conversations with dear friends.

At the Heart of Mantra, we want to welcome Travelers and fellow Artists from all over the World. Offering Art Residencies of 3 to 6 months. We want to crossbreed ideas from people’s passions, palettes and personal stories as to help Leon become the Art and Design center of El Bajío.

And, while doing this very important mission, we want to Have Fun with You!

 Leon is evolving an incredible night life in downtown Madero Street.  Come Celebrate with Us!


Con tu apoyo fundaremos el primer hostal de Arte dedicado a patrocinar artistas locales y globales en la ciudad de León, Guanajuato, México.

Helfen Sie uns, die erste Herberge gefunden gewidmet Kunst in Mexiko zu sponsern.

Aide nous avons trouvé la première auberge de l'art au Mexique dédié à parrainer les créateurs mondiaux.


メキシコでアートをスポンサーに特化した最初
のホステルを発見するために私たちを助けます


What do we have to offer:

Casa del Viento - Bar and artists gathering place.

This is where our project got started, my good artist friends provided the initial support, referrals and a place to get together. This is the main retreat for fun, just across the street.


 Mantra Hostal View and location: 

In a Friday, like many in Casa del Viento, we were referred to Mantra Hostel property. When we climbed to the roof, Love at first sight ! 

Mantra Hostel is located at Motolinia 109, Leon, Guanajuato, Mexico, we are two blocks from downtown center, a 20 min walk from Stadium and Bus Station.



 Mantra local and global art:
Like our first open gallery exhibition from our friend and first resident artist, Coatl Gudha.


And our dear friend Antonio Ehrenzweig.


 Mantra Hostel Picture:

This house was a Horse Stable, a priest House, a Family Home for several generations. Last intervention dates from 1930´s, according to floor style. Property records date back from eighteen century. 



Where the heck is Leon?
Leon is becoming an strategical place in Mexico, for long a shoe epicenter of the world,  within 2 hours drive from Guadalajara, San Miguel de Allende and Queretaro. Guanajuato is a 30 mins drive from here. 
A great anual fair running in January and the famous Festival Cervantino. We are still surrounded by mountains of silver and gold that helped the Spanish folks drive their empire for quite a while.
Top 3 visits in the city:
  • Foro Cultural and Museo del Estado
  • Plaza del Expiatorio Cathedral
  • The Shoe Outlets.
Top 5 visits in Guanajuato.
  • Guanajuato Mummies
  • Gold and Silver Mines.
  • Aurora Art Gallery in San Miguel de Allende.
  • Mineral de Pozos magic town.
  • Hacienda de Jaral de Berrios.
Perks:

Stick your Tongue Out:

We will create and ship a sticker to any size you want up to 30 x 30 cm from the following three models:
1) Color

2) Black and White


3) Hand Draw study:



Your Name Welcomes the World
Antonio Ehrenzweig will create a 15 x 15 cm marble tile with Your Name to adorn the walls and columns of the Hostel reception. Your name inmortal welcoming the world !



PRET A PORTER MEMBERSHIP.

Shirts can be of the logo Designs shown for stickers or choose for a free style shirt just created for you.

FREE NIGHTS

  • Your first Nights Perk redemption is FREE as Beer, further visits will need to purchase at least a night to redeem you category Gratis Nights.
  • Free Nights can be redeemed a maximum of 2 times a year. 
  • We will check for your name in the Wall of Welcoming Fame or your Pret at Porter shirt. 
  • Otherwise a pretty good deal,  right?

What We Need and how you can Help

Property was acquired in Sep 2015 and  local contractors have estimated the following. 

  • US $ 8,000 to create bathroom and shower infrastructure with Solar Boilers.
  • US $ 4,000 to build bedroom bunk beds inspired by our friends at Downtown Beds in Mexico City. These are very quiet beds with upgraded light and charging systems.
Stretch Goal:
  • US $10,000 to modernize electric installation which includes photovoltaics cells and led lighting.



Your Good Hearted Local and Global impact.

  • You will make people happy, there will be happy well paid employees serving happy travelers from all over the world. 
  • We will support and showcase sustainable technologies and markets.
  • You will help develop a local art scene with global ambitions.


Risks & Challenges

This project is happening, your support will help us to speed up opening ceremony !
  • Our team has created Sustainable Buildings, Big Festivals and Global software projects. More hands are showing to help.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Make Noise ! Leon is prime location for Travel, share with your friends. 
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
This year AfrikaBurn celebrates its 10th anniversary with the mythical symbol «X» as the theme of the event. So what does "X" mean? A letter, a number or a symbol – everyone can find his own meaning. For our project "The Moment", we consider «X» in the context of time - a point between the past and the future is a crucial moment in time, called "X".

The Own Way Team

Own Way team is from Russia. Each member of our team is a professional in his own sphere – we are architects, engineers, designers, artists, interior decorators, cameramen, writers, translators, event managers, and mischief makers. We have created numerous installations and art objects for festivals in our own country and several projects for Burning Man: Cradle of Mir project (2013), the Russian Library Souk (2014) and Own Way (2015).

"The Cradle of MIR" at Burning Man 2013


"Own Way" timelapse at Burning man 2015

How "The Moment" Looks Like?

Our object takes the form of a great egg held high in the air by nine living arteries. They seek to keep it safe and sound, to protect it, but a crack has already appeared in the shell – and that means its fate is already sealed. You can take one of the arteries and climb inside the egg, be alone with your thoughts. Recognizing the inevitability of change, we suggest you savor the moment, as soon enough a fire will break out of the center of the embryo, destroying the shell. And then the miracle of birth will take place. A new era will begin…


upd:


What the Money will Go To

This year, Own Way was awarded a grant from AfrikaBurn that covered only materials from which the object was built.  We will still need to be supplied with art object transport to the Playa (sea cargo shipment) which is not cheap as it is coming from so far away. We are in real need of the generous support of crowdfunders – of all of you who want eventually to remember their own moment, anyone who appreciates our vision and would want to see the project built.

Help us to make our idea a reality, to let everyone at this year's AfrikaBurn enjoy "the moment!"

Rewards

Check out Gallery for more images.

Follow us on Instagram, Facebook, Vkontakte and Twitter!

story:
We cut up a story into 150 pieces, "BLASPHEMY!" you say?


BUT we got 150 artists to recreate Lewis Carroll's classic into a unique, Sesquicentennial coffee-table edition. Join us now - as we journey to  Wonderland!


Disclaimer: Please note shipping prices at the end of this campaign page before backing.

150Alice is a project celebrating the 150th anniversary of Lewis Carroll’s Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland.  We brought together 150 brilliant artists from 42 countries to promote their artwork in a unique way and give them an opportunity to create a masterpiece together.



Our version of Alice's Adventures in Wonderland is a fully illustrated 300-page hardcover book, made up of 150 pages of text and 150 vibrant illustrations accompanying each page. We restyled the original text into 150 segments, and sent each piece to an artist to imagine that piece in their own way.

The result is a unique edition showcasing varied art styles from all over the world. It is also a chance for the artists to showcase their own skills, and most importantly, a chance for us, the artists, and you, to give back to society through art.

Each book measures 28x28x3.5cm, weighs a hefty 3kg, and is sure to add colour to your living room, and life to your coffee table. Now, Lewis Carroll will be pleased, won't he?



Lewis Carroll created Wonderland, and the story surrounding it, out of his love of entertaining children. 150 years later, Alice's Adventures in Wonderland is still enjoyed by children all over the world through books, games, movies and art.

We are here to drive forward Lewis Carroll’s idea of encouraging art and creativity among children. With your generous support, we can help a generation of children develop a more vivid imagination.

Our end goal is to build an art school in Mongolia, a place where children can go to learn, experiment and play with their imagination. For a start, we are working with the Independent Research Institute of Mongolia (IRIM) to conduct regular art classes at Secondary School Number 3 in Zuunkharaa Soum, Selenge, Mongolia.

These art classes, while held in the school, are also open to children in the neighbourhood. At class, children will learn various forms of art, from basic drawing and painting, to traditional Mongolian wood sculpturing. Through this, we hope to encourage them to find new opportunities for themselves, and add colour to their lives and communities. 

All proceeds from the sale of the book and its related products will be used towards educating children in Mongolia about art and creativity. We are working with Mrs. Dash Oyunchimeg, the spouse of the Ambassador from Mongolia to China, to find partners in Mongolia who can help us make this dream a reality.




DISCLAIMER FOR UNITED STATES AND CANADA BACKERS: Please note that contrary to information found on Indiegogo's purchase page that shipping to these areas are free, they are not. Shipping charges will apply to these countries as well, with exact charges found in the full shipping list at the end of the campaign page.

ALSO do note that although we mention that shipping is to be left out till the campaign is fully funded, backers may include shipping immediately when selecting their perk, as a side donation.




We would love to deliver the books right to your doorstep, and that is exactly what we are going to do. But that is not something we can make happen as simply as it sounds, which is why we seek your understanding to add the appropriate shipping fees after selecting your perks.

The shipping  amount to be added is based on your location, which you can quickly refer to the map below for. For more detailed information, such as the full list of countries we can ship to and the exact cost to each country, please refer to the shipping list at the end of this campaign page.

Please note that for backers who live in countries where VAT and other import taxes apply, these additional fees are to be borne by the backer. The 150Alice team will not be held liable for any extra fees applicable within individual countries. We appreciate your kind understanding.


Hey, we are so sure you would love the book that this is what we're willing to do: all unsatisfied backers can exercise a 100% money back option within 30 days upon receiving the book. Simply write in to let us know and we will arrange for the return of the book. In exchange, you will receive the full amount of your pledge back. 

Too much of a hassle? We think so too, but don't worry for returning the book will not even be a consideration. Like we said, you will love it.

Now that you've gotten our guarantee that the purchase is risk-free, what are you waiting for? Hurry, back us now!






The 150Alice Project was born out of Pickatale's own vision for creative education and child literacy. At Pickatale, we do interactive children storybooks, and 150Alice is our side project to further help spread art and creative education which we see as a crucial part of every kid's childhood.

With your help, our dream of promoting healthy childhood development through art education and literacy can be achieved. Have you met the team yet? If not, now's the time to say hi!


Help us spread the word about this amazing project among your friends, and get them to join our cause! For more updates, information and eye candy:

Like and follow us on Facebook: http://facebook.com/150alice
Follow us on Twitter: @150alice
Follow us on Instagram: @150alice

#150Alice


Email: contact@150alice.com


Do you accept PayPal? 

Yes, Indiegogo supports both PayPal and credit cards!

How do I add Shipping? 

Shipping is added automatically when you enter your shipping address. Please see the shipping chart for shipping fees by region.

Why is international shipping so expensive? 

First off, we want to acknowledge that the cost of shipping internationally is expensive. We are working with multiple carriers in search of the best solution to ship these books. Most importantly, we want the book to arrive safe and fast at your doorstep.The book weighs about 3kg which increases the cost by a huge amount. 

Where do I add my shipping address? 

You can add it when you contribute. 

My country isn't listed under your shipping list.

Unfortunately, we are not able to ship everywhere in the world. In case you really want the book but your country is not listed, please contact us directly at contact@pickatale.com and we will see what we can arrange.

You said the electronic version is "protected". What does that mean? 

It means that the electronic version cannot be copied, and can only be viewed by people who purchased it.

Why are you called 150Alice? 

We started this project knowing that 2015 would be the 150th anniversary of Alice's Adventures in Wonderland. We kept that theme throughout everything we did, including finding 150 wonderful artists to illustrate this book.

What are the risks? 

The main risk is making sure that you get this book on time and that it is the greatest book you have ever owned. That's no small task, but we are serious when we say that you will love every single page of this book or you get your money back. If you are unsure about anything contact us here: contact@pickatale.com

story:
Santa Fe Art Institute Artists Residency in July

The beginning of this year started fierce with major intense change that shifted everything. But now I will gather myself and move forward to the possibilities of the future and growth. From July 1-26, 2015 I have been granted an artist residency at Santa Fe Art Institute, I need your support to assist in this journey.


Santa Fe Art Institute

At this residency I will not only produce a new work but it will be a personal journey that will lead me to make art within a land I have yet to explore. Joining me will be local histories, Native American stories of the Southwest, and my Mother who I ask to lead and guide me.

OUTPOST Artists Resources

Once I return, during August I have been offered a new media residency at OUTPOST: Cuts and Burns Artist Residency in Ridgewood, NY. Where I will get professional post-production assistance in audio mixing and editing.


ABOUT PROJECT

While at SFAI I'll focus on the following:
  • Working Project Title:
    VAGABOND
  • Concepts:
    [1] Vanishing & Loss
    Loss of one's cultural identity. I am interested in asking the question how does one maintain and preserve their culture? What is it like to not have either, how does one function and communicate with surrounding communities and environments around them? What is lost and what is gained? How does one maintain a sense of self?
    • [2] Home
    How does one define and experience home? What different forms can it take? I will make and invite the public to make forms of home, referencing traditional and contemporary Southwest craft practices.
  • Constructed Character:
    I will create Nomadic characters who do not have a family, home, and who do not know their origin. They will find their identity through communication with the people they meet, objects, stories, and interaction with the land through their travels.
  • Historical Reference:
    Throughout my work I will reference the history of the Pueblo Revolt as revisited by Michal Wilcox in ‘The Pueblo Revolt and the Mythology of Conquest An Indigenous Archaeology of Contact.' I am interested in how this conflict liberated and helped to persevere the identities of the Pueblo tribes in New Mexico. What aspects of self were gained and what was lost that could not be regained?


MATERIALS  [Updated!]

The materials used in this project will consist mainly of gold and silver emergency blankets, sun dried terracotta (red clay), water, and wood.  

WOVEN BASKETS FOR THE 'OBJECTS OF HOME'

I have begun testing materials to hold the 'objects of home' that I will carry upon my back while performing in NM. I have decided to use outdoor safety & utility rope for these forms. ** 
They come in a variety of colors and I am excited to begin mixing and testing which ones work best for the project. 

**NOTE: There is a perk that offers the chance to get one of these smaller forms containing a special surprise nested inside.


SCULPTURAL OBJECTS

Special thanks to Emcee C.M., Master of None for assistance in construction.

Currently in production is a few object pieces I'll be using in my project. One is a four sided triangle form that opens up to become a compass with a graphic element, activate by a bell like form. It will help guild the nomadic characters as they move along the New Mexico landscape.
Also, I am working on a modular construction made of units that can hold small objects that will be carried like a backpack, easily to put together and take apart like a tent. I aim to construct the pieces for this form here to assemble while at SFAI and add to if needed.


PUBLIC PARTICIPATION

I will invite the public who come to visit my studio at SFAI to make dolls-like forms in concept of home. I am curious why one chooses these forms and what each means to them. What aspects of home gives one power and identity.

I will then take these forms with the ones I have produced and bring them along with me to the desert using them in constructed performance rituals.

The forms I will be researching are Kachina dolls made by Pueblo tribes of the Southwest. These dolls are considered to be Spirit beings; they can represent anything in the natural world or cosmos, from a revered ancestor to an element, a location, a quality, a natural phenomenon, or a concept.

I want to connect the idea that home can be more then just a room with four walls or a structure containing belongings. What symbols and ideas of home hold power for us, if so why?

PROJECT NEED

The support you give will help cover the following:

Residency Fee = $900

Travel = $875

  • Flight from to NYC to Albuquerque, New Mexico $350
  • Train to Santa Fe $30
  • I will also need a rental car to get around from one shoot location to the other. Some locations are 1-3 hrs away from SFAI $165 week x 3 weeks= $ 495
Lodging = $300
      Overnight stays at camping grounds and Airbnb rentals along travel routs.

Local Artist Hire = $200 +
I am in the process of having an earth wear piece produced by a local New Mexican artist in Santa Fe made of terracotta mixed from local earth to be used in the constructed performance rituals. This will not only give me a chance to collaborate with a local artist but also help me support their art practice. I will also be looking for performers to hire & volunteer for the project.

Total Funding Need: $ 2,275


PROJECT SIGNIFICANCE

This project will bring a contemporary spotlight to the history of the first independent attempt by the Pueblo tribes of Santa Fe against Colonization.

It will be a journey where I will encourage the sharing of stories of 'home' by locals and those who visit SFAI. They will also have a chance to be a part of the project by making personalized 'Home Dolls' that will then be incorporated into my video and installations.

Along this journey I will face the loss of my own home after the passing of my mother last December. In my travels through the desert there will be a series of constructed rituals that will incorporate the releasing of my Mother's ashes. I hope to find a peace and allow her to find rest in these lands. 


RISKS & CHALLENGES

[1] Time-frame (4 weeks)
[2] Unfamiliarity w/ location
[3] Finding & scheduling performers
[4] Pre-scouting before shoot
[5] Shooting in the desert
[6] Finalizing first cut of video


HOW I WILL FACE THESE CHALLENGES:

[1]
I will set a detailed production schedule leaving room for changes but it will create a base to begin the project on and keep the work on track. 

[2 & 3]
I have not worked at this location in the past which means I will have to solidify talent commitments and collaborators once I arrive in July. I have begun researching and contacting local performing who have already shown interest in being involved in the project.

[4]
Scouting plays a major roll in my work and being able to spend a significant amount of time within a location enables me to better work in the space. Once I arrive I will begin scouting for areas to shoot, this could take a number of days to route.

[5]
Plan to bring lots of WATER! I will also test the camera's sensor limit in different hot environments, and take break times into account.  

[6]
If all goes as planned I should be able to create a rough first-cut by the end of the SFAI residency, and continue to refine it at OUTPOST: Cuts and Burns AiR. If any delays in production arise I will send out a update right away.

OTHER WAYS TO HELP

No worries if you are unable to contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:
  • Call out to all the awesome people you know! It would be extremely helpful if you could assist in getting the word out and make some noise about this campaign and help make connections with possibly interested supporters. 
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools. It is super easy with one click and 'poof' the interconnections begin.


THANK YOU!!!

Thank you so much for taking the time to check out this campaign page! Much warm thanks for supporting my upcoming project. It always amazes me how things come together and every little part helps in the making.
story_txt:
Santa Fe Art Institute Artists Residency in July



The beginning of this year started fierce with major intense
change that shifted everything. But now I will gather myself and
move forward to the possibilities of the future and growth. From July 1-26, 2015 I have been granted an artist residency at Santa Fe Art Institute, I need your support to assist in this journey.
Santa Fe Art Institute



At this residency I will not only produce a new work
but it will be a personal journey that will lead me to make art within a land I
have yet to explore. Joining me will be local histories, Native American stories of the Southwest, and
my Mother who I ask to lead and guide me.



OUTPOST Artists Resources
Once I return, during August I have been offered a new media residency at OUTPOST: Cuts and Burns Artist Residency
in Ridgewood, NY. Where I will get
professional post-production assistance in audio mixing and editing. 

ABOUT PROJECT
While at SFAI I'll focus on the following: 

Working Project Title:VAGABOND

Concepts:[1] Vanishing & LossLoss of one's cultural identity. I am interested in asking the question how does one maintain and 
preserve their culture? What is it like to not have either, how does one
 function and communicate with surrounding communities and environments around 
them? What is lost and what is gained? How does one maintain a sense of self?
[2] Home How does one define and experience home? What different forms can it take? I will make and invite the public to make forms of home, referencing traditional and contemporary Southwest craft practices.
Constructed Character:I will create Nomadic characters
who do not have a family, home, and who do not know their origin. They will find
their identity through communication with the people they meet, objects,
stories, and interaction with the land through their travels. 

Historical Reference:Throughout my work
I
will reference the history of the Pueblo Revolt as revisited by Michal Wilcox in ‘The Pueblo Revolt and the Mythology of Conquest An Indigenous Archaeology of Contact.' I am interested in how this conflict liberated and
helped to persevere the identities of the Pueblo tribes in New Mexico. What
aspects of self were gained and what was lost that could not be regained?





MATERIALS  [Updated!]



The materials used in this project will consist mainly
of gold and silver emergency blankets, sun dried terracotta (red clay), water, and wood.  
WOVEN BASKETS FOR THE 'OBJECTS OF HOME' 

I have begun testing materials to hold the 'objects of home' that I will carry upon my back while performing in NM. I have decided to use outdoor safety & utility rope for these forms. **  They come in a variety of colors and I am excited to begin mixing and testing which ones work best for the project.  **NOTE: There is a perk that offers the chance to get one of these smaller forms containing a special surprise nested inside.

I have produced and bring them along with me to the desert using them in
constructed performance rituals. 


The forms I will be researching are Kachina dolls made by
Pueblo tribes of the Southwest. These dolls are considered to be Spirit
beings; they
can represent anything in the natural world or cosmos, from a revered ancestor
to an element, a location, a quality, a natural phenomenon, or a concept.

Travel = $875

$350

Train to Santa Fe $30

week x 3 weeks= $ 495
